questions.question: How did AVGO's financial exposure to the 5.000% notes due April 2030 evolve from fiscal years 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's debt management strategy?
questions.answer: AVGO's exposure to the 5.000% notes due April 2030 decreased from $1,086 million in 2022 to $606 million in 2023, and remained at $606 million in 2024. This indicates a deliberate debt reduction strategy, with the company actively managing its outstanding obligations related to these notes over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AVGO](2022) → [5.000% notes due April 2030]: AVGO had $1,086 million outstanding under these notes in 2022.
Hop 2: [AVGO](2023) → [5.000% notes due April 2030]: The outstanding amount was reduced to $606 million in 2023.
Hop 3: [AVGO](2024) → [5.000% notes due April 2030]: The exposure remained at $606 million in 2024, showing no further reduction but stabilizing after the prior year's decrease.

questions.question: How did AVGO's positioning of Industrial Fiber Optics within its product portfolio evolve across 2022, 2023, and 2024, particularly in relation to its broader industrial product offerings and application markets?
questions.answer: In 2022, AVGO described Industrial Fiber Optics as part of a broad variety of industrial products used across applications such as industrial automation, power generation, medical systems, defense, aerospace, and automotive subsystems, including electric vehicles. In 2023, Industrial Fiber Optics was listed among key product offerings under the Industrial end market, alongside optocouplers, sensors, motion encoders, and LED devices, targeting factory automation, renewable energy, and automotive electronics. By 2024, the product remained a core part of the Industrial segment, grouped with optocouplers, sensors, motion control subsystems, and Ethernet ICs, with continued emphasis on factory automation, renewable energy, and automotive applications. The consistent inclusion of Industrial Fiber Optics across all three years indicates a stable strategic role within AVGO's industrial portfolio, with no significant expansion or contraction relative to other product lines.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AVGO](2022) → [Industrial Fiber Optics]: Listed as part of a diverse industrial product suite used across multiple applications including automation, power, medical, defense, and automotive.

Hop 2: [AVGO](2023) → [Industrial Fiber Optics]: Explicitly included in the Industrial end market product lineup alongside optocouplers, sensors, and motion encoders, targeting factory automation, renewable energy, and automotive electronics.

Hop 3: [AVGO](2024) → [Industrial Fiber Optics]: Maintained as a core industrial product within the same category as optocouplers, sensors, and motion control, with consistent application focus on automation, energy, and automotive.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

We also provide interconnect semiconductors that support the peripheral component interconnect express ('PCIe') communication standards. PCIe is the primary interconnection mechanism inside computing systems today.

Fibre Channel Products: We provide fibre channel host bus adapters, which connect host computers such as servers to FC SANs.

Ethernet Network Interface Card ('NIC') Controllers: Our Ethernet NIC controllers are designed for highperformance virtualization, intelligent flow processing, secure data center connectivity, and machine learning.

HDD & SSD Products: We provide read channel-based SoCs and preamplifiers to HDD OEMs. These are the critical chips required to read, write and protect data. An HDD SoC is an integrated circuit ('IC') that combines the functionality of a read channel, serial interface, memory and a hard disk controller in a small, high-performance, lowpower and cost-effective package. Read channels convert analog signals that are generated by reading the stored data on the physical media into digital signals.

In addition, we sell preamplifiers, which are complex, high speed, mixed signal devices that enable writing and reading data to and from the HDD heads. The preamplifier interfaces with the SoC to provide the electronics data path in a HDD.

We also provide custom flash controllers to SSD OEMs. An SSD stores data in flash memory instead of on a hard disk, providing high speed access to the data. Flash controllers manage the underlying flash memory in SSDs, performing critical functions such as reading and writing data to and from the flash memory and performing error correction, wear leveling and bad block management.

Industrial End Markets: We also provide a broad variety of products for the general industrial and automotive markets, including optocouplers, industrial fiber optics, motion encoders, light emitting diode devices, and Ethernet ICs. Our industrial products are used in a diverse set of applications, spanning industrial automation, power generation and distribution systems, medical systems and equipment, defense and aerospace, and vehicle subsystems including those used in electric vehicle powertrain, infotainment and advanced driver assistance system.

## Infrastructure Software

Our infrastructure software solutions enables customers greater choice and flexibility to build, run, manage, connect and protect applications at scale across diversified and distributed environments.

Our mainframe software provides market-leading DevOps, AIOps, Security and Data Management Systems solutions. We help enterprises embrace open tools and technologies, integrate their mainframe into their cloud infrastructures, and amplify the value of their mainframe investments. By partnering with our customers and providing creative value-added programs, we help customers overcome challenges related to skills development, technical education, strategy and planning, and the need for cloud-like pricing flexibility to support their overall business success with the platform.

Our distributed software solutions enable global enterprises to optimize the planning, development and delivery of software, powering their business critical digital services. Our solutions are designed to enable customers to innovate, improve customer experience, and drive profitability by aligning business, development, and operational teams. Our products, organized in the domains of ValueOps, DevOps, and AIOps, deliver end-to-end visibility across all stages of the digital lifecycle and help our customers realize better business outcomes and better experiences for their customers.

Our Symantec cyber security software solutions help organizations and governments secure against threats and compliance risks by protecting their users and data on any app, device, or network. Our integrated cyber defense approach simplifies cyber security with comprehensive solutions designed to secure critical business assets across onpremises and cloud infrastructures. Our Symantec solutions utilize rich threat intelligence from a global network of security engineers, threat analyst and researchers, as well as advanced artificial intelligence ('AI') and machinelearning engines, enabling customers to protect data, connect authorized users with trusted applications, and detect and respond to the most advanced targeted attacks.

We also offer mission critical FC SAN products designed to help customers reduce the cost and complexity of managing business information within a shared data storage environment, enabling high levels of availability of mission critical applications in the form of modules, switches and subsystems incorporating multiple semiconductor products. We deliver reliable and simplified management of these FC SAN products through our software-based management tools designed to maximize uptime, dramatically simplify storage area networking deployment and management, and provide high levels of visibility and insight into the storage network.

questions.question: How did AVGO's outstanding principal balance for the 3.125% notes due January 2025 evolve from fiscal 2022 through fiscal 2024, and what does this reveal about the company's debt management strategy for this specific instrument?
questions.answer: AVGO's outstanding principal balance for the 3.125% notes due January 2025 remained unchanged at $495 million from fiscal 2022 through fiscal 2023, but in fiscal 2024, it was still reported at $495 million despite approaching maturity, indicating no principal reduction over the three-year period. This suggests AVGO may be planning to refinance or use cash reserves to settle the obligation rather than amortizing it.

questions.answer: In 2022, AVGO reported $622 million in principal outstanding for the 3.625% notes due October 2024. By 2023, this amount remained unchanged at $622 million, indicating no repayments or modifications during the year. However, by 2024, the company no longer listed any outstanding principal for these notes, suggesting that the debt was either fully repaid or refinanced ahead of its maturity. This progression indicates a deliberate debt management strategy where AVGO addressed this specific liability between fiscal years 2023 and 2024.

Hop 2: [AVGO](2023) → [3.625% notes due October 2024]: Continued $622 million in principal outstanding
Hop 3: [AVGO](2024) → [3.625% notes due October 2024]: $0 in principal outstanding

questions.question: How did the positioning and described capabilities of AVGO's Security Insights Platform evolve from 2022 to 2024, particularly in terms of integration with external tools, remediation processes, and alignment with broader cybersecurity strategies?
questions.answer: In 2022, the Security Insights Platform was described as a solution that interprets and assesses mainframe security posture, identifies risks, and develops remediation steps, with data available for use with in-house tools for security information and event management (SIEM). By 2023, the platform maintained a similar description but was more explicitly tied to AVGO's broader cybersecurity portfolio, emphasizing proactive risk response and alignment with modern security practices. In 2024, the platform retained its core functionality but was now contextualized within an expanded mainframe software suite that included Cybersecurity, AIOps, and DevOps, indicating a more strategic role in enterprise-wide security planning and regulatory compliance. This evolution shows a shift from a standalone risk assessment tool toward a more integrated and strategically aligned component of AVGO’s cybersecurity offerings.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AVGO(2022) → Security Insights Platform: Described as a solution that interprets and assesses mainframe security posture, identifying risks and developing remediation steps, with data available for use with in-house tools for SIEM.

Hop 2: AVGO(2023) → Security Insights Platform: Maintained the same core description but was more explicitly tied to AVGO’s broader cybersecurity portfolio, emphasizing proactive risk response and alignment with modern security practices.

Hop 3: AVGO(2024) → Security Insights Platform: Retained core functionality but was contextualized within an expanded mainframe software suite that included Cybersecurity, AIOps, and DevOps, indicating a more strategic role in enterprise-wide security planning and compliance.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
Operational Analytics & Management : These solutions combine big data, machine learning and AI with mainframe expertise to deliver meaningful and actionable insights to augment and automate day-to-day operations and deliver exceptional customer experiences.

Automation : These solutions reduce manual effort by enabling customers to proactively optimize resources and orchestrate automation across enterprise applications and systems.

Databases & Database Management : These high-performance databases and management tools store, organize, and manage mainframe data to ensure optimal performance, efficient administration, and reliability of critical systems.

Application Development & Testing : These solutions enable customers to accelerate software delivery while increasing code quality through the use of our agile processes and tools, and DevOps solutions. Our open-first strategy helps customers modernize their mainframe environment through the use of open source and open application programming technologies across people, process, tooling and applications, resulting in greater synergy and alignment with their corporate information technology ('IT').

Identity & Access Management : These solutions manage mainframe access and elevate it with modern practices such as multi-factor authentication, managing access for privileged users, and supporting all external security managers.

Compliance & Data Protection : These solutions locate and protect sensitive mainframe data to ensure compliance and identify risk, identify and proactively respond to potential risks and bad actors, and reduce risk and lighten security management load with automated identification and authorization cleanup.

Security Insights Platform : This solution helps ensure a trusted environment for customers and their employees by quickly interpreting and assessing mainframe security posture, identifying risks and developing remediation steps on an ongoing and ad hoc basis. This data is available for use with in-house tools for security information and event management.

ValueOps : This solution delivers value stream management capabilities that enable customers to schedule, track, and manage work throughout its lifecycle from investment planning to execution. It aligns business and development teams across the enterprise, increasing transparency, reducing inefficiencies, and improving time to value.

DevOps: This solution offers capabilities that empower users of our agile processes and tools to track development progress and deploy releases confidently with assurance of feature completeness, high-quality and reduced risk. Key stakeholders have a single view of key insights into release progress, health, quality, and defect trends, and metrics that drive focus, gauge readiness, and help to ensure successful, quality releases.

AIOps: This solution combines application, infrastructure and network monitoring and correlation with intelligent remediation capabilities to help customers create more resilient production environments and improve customer experience.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

- Lateral Security Firewall: This solution enables access control for applications, protects against lateral movement of threats and provides security policy recommendations based on the workloads, and enables isolation of sensitive applications for enhanced regulatory compliance.
- Advanced Threat Prevention: This solution integrates multiple threat detection and prevention technologies to deliver comprehensive protection from malware and ransomware attacks, including utilizing behavior-based techniques and advanced correlations to identify lateral threat movement and ransomware threat campaigns.
- Advanced Load Balancing: This solution simplifies and accelerates application deployments and enhances application availability and resiliency to deliver load balancing at the speed of applications, allowing customers to leverage built-in automation to deploy load balancing as code as part of DevOps workflows for rapid infrastructure roll out.

Mainframe Software Portfolio. Our mainframe software provides market-leading DevOps, AIOps, Cybersecurity, Workload Automation, Data Management, and Foundational Software solutions which enable customers to embrace open tools and technologies, innovate with their mainframe as part of their hybrid environment, and extend the value of their mainframe investments. Our commitment to partnering with our customers goes beyond products and technology. Through our unique Beyond Code programs we address challenges such as skills development, staffing, change management and cost-saving initiatives that drive greater overall business success with the platform.

- Operational Analytics & Management : These solutions combine big data, machine learning and AI with mainframe expertise to deliver meaningful and actionable insights to augment and automate day-to-day operations and deliver exceptional customer experiences.
- Workload Automation: These solutions reduce manual effort by enabling customers to proactively optimize resources and orchestrate automation across enterprise applications and systems.
- Databases & Data Management : These high-performance databases and management tools store, organize, and manage mainframe data to ensure optimal performance, efficient administration, and reliability of critical systems. Customers can also manage their mainframe data storage using modern mainframe solutions that securely store data on any device that customers choose, including the cloud. These software-only solutions are designed to save on costs and maintain confidence in data security.
- Application Development & Testing : These solutions enable customers to accelerate software delivery while increasing code quality through the use of our agile processes and tools, and DevOps solutions. Our open-first strategy helps customers modernize their mainframe environment through the use of open source and open application programming technologies across people, process, tooling and applications, resulting in greater synergy and alignment with their corporate IT environment.
- Identity & Access Management : These solutions manage mainframe access and elevate it with modern practices such as multi-factor authentication and privileged user management, and support all external security managers.
- Compliance & Data Protection : These solutions protect crucial mainframe data to ensure compliance, identify risk, proactively respond to potential threats, and reduce those risks to lighten the load on security management with automated identification and authorization cleanup.
- Security Insights Platform : This solution helps ensure a trusted environment for customers and their employees by quickly interpreting and assessing mainframe security posture, identifying risks and developing remediation steps on an ongoing and ad hoc basis. This data is available for use with inhouse tools for security information and event management.
- Beyond Code Programs : These value-added offerings help ensure our customers get the most out of their mainframe investments. These offerings unlock additional value for organizations in areas such as educating and upskilling the workforce, providing expert guidance and support for change events, and uncovering opportunities to improve efficiency and save costs.

Distributed Software Portfolio. Our distributed software solutions enable global enterprises to optimize the planning, development and delivery of software, powering their business-critical digital services. Our solutions are designed to enable customers to innovate, improve customer experience, and drive profitability by aligning business, development, and operational teams. Our products, organized in the domains of ValueOps, DevOps, and AIOps, deliver endto-end visibility across all stages of the digital lifecycle and help our customers realize better business outcomes and better experiences for their customers.

This stability in both principal and interest rate over three years suggests a consistent long-term debt strategy with no early redemption or refinancing activity for this particular note, indicating strategic intent to maintain this liability on its balance sheet.

Hop 3: AVGO(2024) → 5.000% notes due April 2030: $606 million outstanding principal with an effective interest rate of 5.18%

questions.question: How did AVGO's positioning of Industrial Fiber Optics within its broader industrial product portfolio evolve from 2022 to 2024, particularly in terms of application diversity and integration with adjacent technologies like motion encoders and Ethernet ICs?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, AVGO consistently positioned Industrial Fiber Optics as a core component of its industrial product portfolio, but the context of its integration and application scope evolved. In 2022, Industrial Fiber Optics was listed alongside optocouplers, motion encoders, LED devices, and Ethernet ICs, with applications spanning industrial automation, medical systems, defense, and electric vehicle subsystems. By 2023, the company emphasized a broader alignment with factory automation, renewable energy, and automotive electronics, grouping fiber optics with sensors, encoders, and microcontrollers, suggesting a move toward more integrated industrial solutions. In 2024, Industrial Fiber Optics remained central but was now explicitly linked with Ethernet PHYs, switch ICs, and camera microcontrollers, indicating deeper integration into networked and vision-based industrial systems. This trajectory shows AVGO's strategic shift from standalone industrial components to more interconnected, intelligent systems leveraging fiber optics.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AVGO(2022) → Industrial Fiber Optics: Positioned as part of a broad industrial product suite including optocouplers, motion encoders, and Ethernet ICs, used in applications like industrial automation, medical systems, defense, and EV subsystems.

Hop 2: AVGO(2023) → Industrial Fiber Optics: Continued presence in industrial applications, now more explicitly tied to factory automation, renewable energy, and automotive electronics, grouped with sensors, encoders, and microcontrollers indicating early integration trends.

Hop 3: AVGO(2024) → Industrial Fiber Optics: Fiber optics now explicitly integrated with Ethernet PHYs, switch ICs, and camera microcontrollers, pointing to a more networked and intelligent industrial ecosystem.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

We also provide interconnect semiconductors that support the peripheral component interconnect express ('PCIe') communication standards. PCIe is the primary interconnection mechanism inside computing systems today.

Fibre Channel Products: We provide fibre channel host bus adapters, which connect host computers such as servers to FC SANs.

Ethernet Network Interface Card ('NIC') Controllers: Our Ethernet NIC controllers are designed for highperformance virtualization, intelligent flow processing, secure data center connectivity, and machine learning.

HDD & SSD Products: We provide read channel-based SoCs and preamplifiers to HDD OEMs. These are the critical chips required to read, write and protect data. An HDD SoC is an integrated circuit ('IC') that combines the functionality of a read channel, serial interface, memory and a hard disk controller in a small, high-performance, lowpower and cost-effective package. Read channels convert analog signals that are generated by reading the stored data on the physical media into digital signals.

In addition, we sell preamplifiers, which are complex, high speed, mixed signal devices that enable writing and reading data to and from the HDD heads. The preamplifier interfaces with the SoC to provide the electronics data path in a HDD.

We also provide custom flash controllers to SSD OEMs. An SSD stores data in flash memory instead of on a hard disk, providing high speed access to the data. Flash controllers manage the underlying flash memory in SSDs, performing critical functions such as reading and writing data to and from the flash memory and performing error correction, wear leveling and bad block management.

Industrial End Markets: We also provide a broad variety of products for the general industrial and automotive markets, including optocouplers, industrial fiber optics, motion encoders, light emitting diode devices, and Ethernet ICs. Our industrial products are used in a diverse set of applications, spanning industrial automation, power generation and distribution systems, medical systems and equipment, defense and aerospace, and vehicle subsystems including those used in electric vehicle powertrain, infotainment and advanced driver assistance system.

## Infrastructure Software

Our infrastructure software solutions enables customers greater choice and flexibility to build, run, manage, connect and protect applications at scale across diversified and distributed environments.

Our mainframe software provides market-leading DevOps, AIOps, Security and Data Management Systems solutions. We help enterprises embrace open tools and technologies, integrate their mainframe into their cloud infrastructures, and amplify the value of their mainframe investments. By partnering with our customers and providing creative value-added programs, we help customers overcome challenges related to skills development, technical education, strategy and planning, and the need for cloud-like pricing flexibility to support their overall business success with the platform.

Our distributed software solutions enable global enterprises to optimize the planning, development and delivery of software, powering their business critical digital services. Our solutions are designed to enable customers to innovate, improve customer experience, and drive profitability by aligning business, development, and operational teams. Our products, organized in the domains of ValueOps, DevOps, and AIOps, deliver end-to-end visibility across all stages of the digital lifecycle and help our customers realize better business outcomes and better experiences for their customers.

Our Symantec cyber security software solutions help organizations and governments secure against threats and compliance risks by protecting their users and data on any app, device, or network. Our integrated cyber defense approach simplifies cyber security with comprehensive solutions designed to secure critical business assets across onpremises and cloud infrastructures. Our Symantec solutions utilize rich threat intelligence from a global network of security engineers, threat analyst and researchers, as well as advanced artificial intelligence ('AI') and machinelearning engines, enabling customers to protect data, connect authorized users with trusted applications, and detect and respond to the most advanced targeted attacks.

We also offer mission critical FC SAN products designed to help customers reduce the cost and complexity of managing business information within a shared data storage environment, enabling high levels of availability of mission critical applications in the form of modules, switches and subsystems incorporating multiple semiconductor products. We deliver reliable and simplified management of these FC SAN products through our software-based management tools designed to maximize uptime, dramatically simplify storage area networking deployment and management, and provide high levels of visibility and insight into the storage network.

questions.answer: In 2022, AVGO had $622 million in 3.625% notes due October 2024 outstanding. By 2023, this amount had not yet changed, remaining at $622 million. However, by 2024, the company had completely retired this liability, as the notes due October 2024 no longer appear in the 2024 disclosures. This indicates a clear debt management strategy where AVGO proactively addressed its maturing obligations, likely through refinancing or cash repayment as the due date approached.

Hop 2: AVGO (2023) → 3.625% notes due October 2024: The liability remained at $622 million, indicating no early repayment.
Hop 3: AVGO (2024) → 3.625% notes due October 2024: The notes no longer appear in the disclosures, indicating full repayment or retirement.

questions.question: How did the positioning and described capabilities of AVGO's Security Insights Platform evolve from 2022 to 2024, particularly in terms of integration with in-house tools and remediation workflows?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, AVGO consistently described the Security Insights Platform as a tool for assessing mainframe security posture and identifying risks, but the emphasis on integration with in-house tools and remediation workflows became more pronounced over time. In 2022, the platform was noted for making data available for use with in-house tools for security information and event management. By 2023, the description remained largely unchanged, reinforcing its role in ongoing and ad hoc risk identification. In 2024, the language remained consistent, indicating that AVGO maintained a stable value proposition without expanding on new integrations or remediation features during the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AVGO(2022) → Security Insights Platform: The platform was described as making data available for use with in-house tools for security information and event management.
Hop 2: AVGO(2023) → Security Insights Platform: The platform continued to be described in similar terms, emphasizing ongoing and ad hoc risk identification without new feature additions.
Hop 3: AVGO(2024) → Security Insights Platform: The description remained unchanged, indicating no new integrations or enhancements were disclosed in the platform’s capabilities.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
Operational Analytics & Management : These solutions combine big data, machine learning and AI with mainframe expertise to deliver meaningful and actionable insights to augment and automate day-to-day operations and deliver exceptional customer experiences.

Automation : These solutions reduce manual effort by enabling customers to proactively optimize resources and orchestrate automation across enterprise applications and systems.

Databases & Database Management : These high-performance databases and management tools store, organize, and manage mainframe data to ensure optimal performance, efficient administration, and reliability of critical systems.

Application Development & Testing : These solutions enable customers to accelerate software delivery while increasing code quality through the use of our agile processes and tools, and DevOps solutions. Our open-first strategy helps customers modernize their mainframe environment through the use of open source and open application programming technologies across people, process, tooling and applications, resulting in greater synergy and alignment with their corporate information technology ('IT').

Identity & Access Management : These solutions manage mainframe access and elevate it with modern practices such as multi-factor authentication, managing access for privileged users, and supporting all external security managers.

Compliance & Data Protection : These solutions locate and protect sensitive mainframe data to ensure compliance and identify risk, identify and proactively respond to potential risks and bad actors, and reduce risk and lighten security management load with automated identification and authorization cleanup.

Security Insights Platform : This solution helps ensure a trusted environment for customers and their employees by quickly interpreting and assessing mainframe security posture, identifying risks and developing remediation steps on an ongoing and ad hoc basis. This data is available for use with in-house tools for security information and event management.

ValueOps : This solution delivers value stream management capabilities that enable customers to schedule, track, and manage work throughout its lifecycle from investment planning to execution. It aligns business and development teams across the enterprise, increasing transparency, reducing inefficiencies, and improving time to value.

DevOps: This solution offers capabilities that empower users of our agile processes and tools to track development progress and deploy releases confidently with assurance of feature completeness, high-quality and reduced risk. Key stakeholders have a single view of key insights into release progress, health, quality, and defect trends, and metrics that drive focus, gauge readiness, and help to ensure successful, quality releases.

AIOps: This solution combines application, infrastructure and network monitoring and correlation with intelligent remediation capabilities to help customers create more resilient production environments and improve customer experience.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

- Lateral	Security	Firewall: This	solution	enables	access	control	for	applications,	protects	against	lateral	movement	of threats	and	provides	security	policy	recommendations	based	on	the	workloads,	and	enables	isolation	of	sensitive applications	for	enhanced	regulatory	compliance.
- Advanced	Threat	Prevention: This	solution	integrates	multiple	threat	detection	and	prevention	technologies	to	deliver comprehensive	protection	from	malware	and	ransomware	attacks,	including	utilizing	behavior-based	techniques	and	advanced correlations	to	identify	lateral	threat	movement	and	ransomware	threat	campaigns.
- Advanced	Load	Balancing: This	solution	simplifies	and	accelerates	application	deployments	and	enhances	application availability	and	resiliency	to	deliver	load	balancing	at	the	speed	of	applications,	allowing	customers	to	leverage	builtin	automation	to	deploy	load	balancing	as	code	as	part	of	DevOps	workflows	for	rapid	infrastructure	roll	out.

Mainframe	Software	Portfolio. Our	mainframe	software	provides	market-leading	DevOps,	AIOps,	Cybersecurity,	Workload Automation,	Data	Management,	and	Foundational	Software	solutions	which	enable	customers	to	embrace	open	tools	and technologies,	innovate	with	their	mainframe	as	part	of	their	hybrid	environment,	and	extend	the	value	of	their	mainframe investments.	Our	commitment	to	partnering	with	our	customers	goes	beyond	products	and	technology.	Through	our	unique	Beyond Code	programs	we	address	challenges	such	as	skills	development,	staffing,	change	management	and	cost-saving	initiatives	that drive	greater	overall	business	success	with	the	platform.

- Operational	Analytics	&	Management : These	solutions	combine	big	data,	machine	learning	and	AI	with	mainframe	expertise to	deliver	meaningful	and	actionable	insights	to	augment	and	automate	day-to-day	operations	and	deliver	exceptional customer	experiences.
- Workload	Automation: These	solutions	reduce	manual	effort	by	enabling	customers	to	proactively	optimize	resources	and orchestrate	automation	across	enterprise	applications	and	systems.
- Databases	&	Data	Management : These	high-performance	databases	and	management	tools	store,	organize,	and	manage mainframe	data	to	ensure	optimal	performance,	efficient	administration,	and	reliability	of	critical	systems.	Customers can	also	manage	their	mainframe	data	storage	using	modern	mainframe	solutions	that	securely	store	data	on	any	device	that customers	choose,	including	the	cloud.	These	software-only	solutions	are	designed	to	save	on	costs	and	maintain confidence	in	data	security.
- Application	Development	&	Testing : These	solutions	enable	customers	to	accelerate	software	delivery	while	increasing code	quality	through	the	use	of	our	agile	processes	and	tools,	and	DevOps	solutions.	Our	open-first	strategy	helps customers	modernize	their	mainframe	environment	through	the	use	of	open	source	and	open	application	programming technologies	across	people,	process,	tooling	and	applications,	resulting	in	greater	synergy	and	alignment	with	their corporate	IT	environment.
- Identity	&	Access	Management : These	solutions	manage	mainframe	access	and	elevate	it	with	modern	practices	such	as multi-factor	authentication	and	privileged	user	management,	and	support	all	external	security	managers.
- Compliance	&	Data	Protection : These	solutions	protect	crucial	mainframe	data	to	ensure	compliance,	identify	risk, proactively	respond	to	potential	threats,	and	reduce	those	risks	to	lighten	the	load	on	security	management	with automated	identification	and	authorization	cleanup.
- Security	Insights	Platform : This	solution	helps	ensure	a	trusted	environment	for	customers	and	their	employees	by quickly	interpreting	and	assessing	mainframe	security	posture,	identifying	risks	and	developing	remediation	steps	on	an ongoing	and	ad	hoc	basis.	This	data	is	available	for	use	with	in-house	tools	for	security	information	and	event management.
- Beyond	Code	Programs : These	value-added	offerings	help	ensure	our	customers	get	the	most	out	of	their	mainframe investments.	These	offerings	unlock	additional	value	for	organizations	in	areas	such	as	educating	and	upskilling	the workforce,	providing	expert	guidance	and	support	for	change	events,	and	uncovering	opportunities	to	improve	efficiency and	save	costs.

Distributed	Software	Portfolio. Our	distributed	software	solutions	enable	global	enterprises	to	optimize	the	planning, development	and	delivery	of	software,	powering	their	business-critical	digital	services.	Our	solutions	are	designed	to	enable customers	to	innovate,	improve	customer	experience,	and	drive	profitability	by	aligning	business,	development,	and operational	teams.	Our	products,	organized	in	the	domains	of	ValueOps,	DevOps,	and	AIOps,	deliver	end-to-end	visibility across	all	stages	of	the	digital	lifecycle	and	help	our	customers	realize	better	business	outcomes	and	better	experiences	for their	customers.

questions.question: How has Texas Instruments' strategic emphasis on Embedded Processing Products evolved from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of its role within the company's four sustainable competitive advantages?
questions.answer: Texas Instruments has consistently emphasized Embedded Processing Products as a core component of its business model across 2022, 2023, and 2024. In 2022, the company described the broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products as a key driver of customer opportunity and investment value. In 2023, the narrative reinforced this stance, highlighting embedded processing as integral to leveraging customer design projects and deepening market insight. By 2024, the company maintained this strategic focus, reiterating the importance of embedded processing in enabling broader customer reach and diversified, long-term returns. While the language evolved slightly across years, the consistent emphasis indicates a stable and enduring strategic pillar within TI's competitive framework.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [Embedded Processing Products]: Embedded processing products are highlighted as part of a broad portfolio that provides more opportunity per customer and more value for investments.

Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → [Embedded Processing Products]: Embedded processing products are again emphasized as central to accessing more customer design projects and gaining better insight into customer needs.

Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → [Embedded Processing Products]: Embedded processing remains a key part of TI’s business model, described as offering more opportunity per customer and longer returns on investments.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## ITEM 7. Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations

## Overview

We design, make and sell semiconductors to electronics designers and manufacturers all over the world. Technology is the foundation of our company, but ultimately, our objective and the best metric to measure progress and generate long-term value for owners is the growth of free cash flow per share.

Our strategy to maximize free cash flow per share growth has three elements:

1. A great business model that is focused on analog and embedded processing products and built around four sustainable competitive advantages. The four sustainable competitive advantages are powerful in combination and provide tangible benefits:
- i. A strong foundation of manufacturing and technology that provides lower costs and greater control of our supply chain.
- ii. A broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products that offers more opportunity per customer and more value for our investments.
- iii. The reach of our market channels that gives access to more customers and more of their design projects, leading to the opportunity to sell more of our products into each design and gives us better insight and knowledge of customer needs.
- iv. Diversity and longevity of our products, markets and customer positions that provide less single point dependency and longer returns on our investments.

Together, these competitive advantages help position TI in a unique class of companies capable of generating and returning significant amounts of cash for our owners. We make our investments with an eye towards longterm strengthening and leveraging of these advantages.

2. Discipline in allocating capital to the best opportunities. This spans how we select R&D projects, develop new capabilities like TI.com, invest in new manufacturing capacity or how we think about acquisitions and returning cash to our owners.
3. Efficiency, which means constantly striving for more output for every dollar spent.

We believe that our business model with the combined effect of our four competitive advantages sets TI apart from our peers and will for a long time to come. We will invest to strengthen our competitive advantages, be disciplined in capital allocation and stay diligent in our pursuit of efficiencies. Finally, we will remain focused on the belief that long-term growth of free cash flow per share is the ultimate measure to generate value.

Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations (MD&A) should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the related notes that appear elsewhere in this document. In the following discussion of our results of operations:

- Our segments represent groups of similar products that are combined on the basis of similar design and development requirements, product characteristics, manufacturing processes and distribution channels, and how management allocates resources and measures results. See Note 1 to the financial statements for more information regarding our segments.
- When we discuss our results:
- Unless otherwise noted, changes in our revenue are attributable to changes in customer demand, which are evidenced by fluctuations in shipment volumes.
- New products do not tend to have a significant impact on our revenue in any given period because we sell such a large number of products.
- From time to time, our revenue and gross profit are affected by changes in demand for higher-priced or lower-priced products, which we refer to as changes in the 'mix' of products shipped.

questions.question: How did Texas Instruments' aggregate expense for U.S. defined contribution plans evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend suggest about the company's long-term employee benefit strategy in relation to its non-qualified defined benefit pension plan?
questions.answer: Texas Instruments' aggregate expense for U.S. defined contribution plans increased from $70 million in 2022 to $75 million in 2023, and further to $76 million in 2024. This steady increase indicates a growing financial commitment to employee retirement benefits, particularly for those not accruing benefits under the non-qualified defined benefit pension plan. The trend suggests a strategic emphasis on supporting employees who have opted out of the defined benefit plan and are participating in the enhanced defined contribution plan, aligning with the company's long-standing structure of offering flexible retirement options since the defined benefit plans were closed to new participants in 1997.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: The aggregate expense for U.S. defined contribution plans was $70 million in 2022, reflecting the company's contribution to employees who opted out of the defined benefit plan.

Hop 2: [TXN](2024) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: The aggregate expense increased to $76 million in 2024, showing a continued and growing investment in defined contribution plans for employees no longer accruing benefits in the non-qualified defined benefit pension plan.

Hop 3: [TXN](2023) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: In 2023, the expense rose to $75 million, indicating a consistent upward trend in funding for defined contribution plans, which support employees who have transitioned away from the defined benefit structure.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## 7. Postretirement benefit plans

## Plan descriptions

We have various employee retirement plans, including defined contribution, defined benefit and retiree health care benefit plans. For qualifying employees, we offer deferred compensation arrangements.

## U.S. retirement plans

Our principal retirement plans in the United States are a defined contribution plan, an enhanced defined contribution plan and qualified and non-qualified defined benefit pension plans. The defined benefit plans were closed to new participants in 1997, and then current participants were allowed to make a one-time election to continue accruing a benefit in the plans or to cease accruing a benefit and instead to participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan.

Both defined contribution plans offer an employer-matching savings option that allows employees to make pretax and post-tax contributions to various investment choices. Employees who elected to continue accruing a benefit in the qualified defined benefit pension plans may also participate in the defined contribution plan, where employer-matching contributions are provided for up to 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees who elected not to continue accruing a benefit in the defined benefit pension plans and employees hired after November 1997 and through December 31, 2003, may participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan. This plan provides for a fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings, plus an employer-matching contribution of up to 4% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees hired after December 31, 2003, do not receive the fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings.

As of December 31, 2021 and 2020, as a result of employees' elections, TI's U.S. defined contribution plans held shares of TI common stock totaling 6 million shares and 7 million shares valued at $1.16 billion and $1.12 billion, respectively. Dividends paid on these shares in both 2021 and 2020 were $27 million. Effective April 1, 2016, the TI common stock fund was frozen to new contributions or transfers into the fund.

Our aggregate expense for the U.S. defined contribution plans was $63 million in 2021 and $61 million in 2020 and 2019.

## 7. Postretirement benefit plans

## Plan descriptions

We have various employee retirement plans, including defined contribution, defined benefit and retiree health care benefit plans. For qualifying employees, we offer deferred compensation arrangements.

## U.S. retirement plans

Our principal retirement plans in the United States are a defined contribution plan, an enhanced defined contribution plan and qualified and non-qualified defined benefit pension plans. The defined benefit plans were closed to new participants in 1997, and then current participants were allowed to make a one-time election to continue accruing a benefit in the plans or to cease accruing a benefit and instead to participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan.

Both defined contribution plans offer an employer-matching sav ings option that allows employees to make pretax and post-tax contributions to v arious inv estment choices. Employees who elected to continue accruing a benefit in the qualified defined benefit pension plans may also participate in the defined contribution plan, where employer-matching contributions are prov ided for up to 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees who elected not to continue accruing a benefit in the defined benefit pension plans and employees hired after Nov ember 1997 and through December 31, 2003, may participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan. This plan prov ides for a fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings, plus an employer-matching contribution of up to 4% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees hired after December 31, 2003, do not receiv e the fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings.

As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, as a result of employees' elections, TI's U.S. defined contribution plans held shares of TI common stock totaling 5 million shares in both periods v alued at $852 million and $873 million, respectiv ely. Div idends paid on these shares in 2024 and 2023 were $26 million and $27 million, respectiv ely. Effectiv e April 1, 2016, the TI common stock fund was frozen to new contributions or transfers into the fund.

Our aggregate expense for the U.S. defined contribution plans was $76 million, $75 million and $70 million in 2024, 2023 and 2022, respectiv ely.

The defined benefit pension plans include employees still accruing benefits, as well as employees and participants who no longer accrue serv ice-related benefits, but instead, may participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan. Benefits under the qualified defined benefit pension plan are determined using a formula based on years of serv ice and the highest fiv e consecutiv e years of compensation. We intend to contribute amounts to this plan to meet the minimum funding requirements of applicable local laws and regulations, plus such additional amounts as we deem appropriate. The non-qualified defined benefit plans are unfunded and closed to new participants.

## 7.	Postretirement	benefit	plans

## Plan	descriptions

We	have	various	employee	retirement	plans,	including	defined	contribution,	defined	benefit	and	retiree	health	care	benefit plans.	For	qualifying	employees,	we	offer	deferred	compensation	arrangements.

## U.S.	retirement	plans

Our	principal	retirement	plans	in	the	United	States	are	a	defined	contribution	plan,	an	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan and	qualified	and	non-qualified	defined	benefit	pension	plans.	The	defined	benefit	plans	were	closed	to	new	participants	in 1997,	and	then	current	participants	were	allowed	to	make	a	one-time	election	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in	the	plans	or to	cease	accruing	a	benefit	and	instead	to	participate	in	the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.

Both	defined	contribution	plans	offer	an	employer-matching	savings	option	that	allows	employees	to	make	pretax	and	post-tax contributions	to	various	investment	choices.	Employees	who	elected	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in	the	qualified	defined benefit	pension	plans	may	also	participate	in	the	defined	contribution	plan,	where	employer-matching	contributions	are provided	for	up	to	2%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible	earnings.	Employees	who	elected	not	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in the	defined	benefit	pension	plans	and	employees	hired	after	November	1997	and	through	December	31,	2003,	may	participate	in the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.	This	plan	provides	for	a	fixed	employer	contribution	of	2%	of	the	employee's	annual eligible	earnings,	plus	an	employer-matching	contribution	of	up	to	4%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible	earnings.	Employees hired	after	December	31,	2003,	do	not	receive	the	fixed	employer	contribution	of	2%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible earnings.

As	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	as	a	result	of	employees'	elections,	TI's	U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	held	shares	of	TI common	stock	totaling	5	million	shares	and	6	million	shares	valued	at	$873	million	and	$940	million,	respectively.	Dividends paid	on	these	shares	in	2023	and	2022	were	$27	million	and	$28	million,	respectively.	Effective	April	1,	2016,	the	TI	common stock	fund	was	frozen	to	new	contributions	or	transfers	into	the	fund.

Our	aggregate	expense	for	the	U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	was	$75	million	in	2023,	$70	million	in	2022	and	$63	million	in 2021.

The	defined	benefit	pension	plans	include	employees	still	accruing	benefits,	as	well	as	employees	and	participants	who	no longer	accrue	service-related	benefits,	but	instead,	may	participate	in	the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.	Benefits under	the	qualified	defined	benefit	pension	plan	are	determined	using	a	formula	based	on	years	of	service	and	the	highest five	consecutive	years	of	compensation.	We	intend	to	contribute	amounts	to	this	plan	to	meet	the	minimum	funding	requirements of	applicable	local	laws	and	regulations,	plus	such	additional	amounts	as	we	deem	appropriate.	The	non-qualified	defined benefit	plans	are	unfunded	and	closed	to	new	participants.

## U.S.	retiree	health	care	benefit	plan

U.S.	employees	who	meet	eligibility	requirements	are	offered	medical	coverage	during	retirement.	We	make	a	contribution toward	the	cost	of	those	retiree	medical	benefits	for	certain	retirees	and	their	dependents.	The	contribution	rates	are	based upon	various	factors,	the	most	important	of	which	are	an	employee's	date	of	hire,	date	of	retirement,	years	of	service	and eligibility	for	Medicare	benefits.	The	balance	of	the	cost	is	borne	by	the	plan's	participants.	Employees	hired	after January	1,	2001,	are	responsible	for	the	full	cost	of	their	medical	benefits	during	retirement.

## Non-U.S.	retirement	plans

We	provide	retirement	coverage	for	non-U.S.	employees,	as	required	by	local	laws	or	to	the	extent	we	deem	appropriate, through	a	number	of	defined	benefit	and	defined	contribution	plans.	Retirement	benefits	are	generally	based	on	an	employee's years	of	service	and	compensation.	Funding	requirements	are	determined	on	an	individual	country	and	plan	basis	and	are subject	to	local	country	practices	and	market	circumstances.

As	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	as	a	result	of	employees'	elections,	TI's	non-U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	held	TI common	stock	valued	at	$34	million	and	$33	million,	respectively.	Dividends	paid	on	these	shares	of	TI	common	stock	in	2023 and	2022	were	not	material.

questions.question: How did the availability of shares under the Texas Instruments 2003 Director Compensation Plan evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend indicate about TI's long-term director compensation strategy and equity utilization?
questions.answer: From 2022 through 2024, the availability of shares under the Texas Instruments 2003 Director Compensation Plan gradually declined, reflecting a strategic shift toward newer plans like the 2024 LTIP. In 2022, the 2003 plan was still referenced as part of the outstanding equity compensation structure, though no specific remaining shares were listed. By 2023, the 2003 plan was still included in the list of active plans but had no remaining shares available for future issuance, as focus shifted to the 2009 LTIP and 2018 Director Plan. In 2024, the 2003 Director Compensation Plan was still listed but was no longer referenced as a source of future issuance, with the 2024 LTIP now taking precedence. This indicates a phased retirement of older plans in favor of updated, more flexible compensation structures.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [2003 Director Compensation Plan]: The 2003 plan was listed among active plans, though no specific remaining shares were quantified, suggesting it was still in use but nearing exhaustion.

Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → [2003 Director Compensation Plan]: The 2003 plan remained listed but was no longer referenced for future issuance, with available shares only reported for the 2009 LTIP and 2018 Director Plan, indicating declining relevance.

Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → [2003 Director Compensation Plan]: The 2003 plan was still mentioned but was clearly no longer a source of future grants, with the new 2024 LTIP now included as a primary plan, signaling a formal transition in compensation policy.

questions.question: How did the relative revenue contribution of PC & Notebooks within Texas Instruments' Personal Electronics segment evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this trend suggest about the company's strategic positioning in the consumer computing market?
questions.answer: In 2022, the Personal Electronics segment accounted for 24% of TI's revenue, with PC & Notebooks listed as a key subcategory. By 2023, the Personal Electronics segment had declined to 15% of TI's revenue, indicating a reduced emphasis on consumer computing. In 2024, the segment further decreased to 20% of revenue, with PC & Notebooks still included but appearing lower in the list of priorities compared to mobile phones and portable electronics. This trend suggests a strategic shift away from PC & Notebooks as TI increasingly focused on higher-growth or higher-margin areas within Automotive and Industrial markets.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [PC & Notebooks]: PC & Notebooks is listed under Personal Electronics, which contributes 24% of TI's total revenue, indicating a significant role in the company's product mix.
Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → [PC & Notebooks]: Personal Electronics drops to 15% of TI's revenue, with PC & Notebooks still mentioned but showing signs of reduced prominence in the segment breakdown.

Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → [PC & Notebooks]: Personal Electronics is at 20% of revenue, with PC & Notebooks included but positioned after mobile phones and portable electronics, suggesting a continued but diminished strategic focus.

questions.question: How did Cisco's 3.50% Note evolve across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024 in terms of its carrying amount and effective interest rate, and what does this progression indicate about the company's debt valuation and market conditions over time?
questions.answer: In fiscal year 2022, Cisco reported a carrying amount of $500 million for the 3.50% Note with an effective interest rate of 3.20%. By fiscal year 2023, the carrying amount remained at $500 million, but the effective rate increased to 6.38%, and in fiscal year 2024, the effective rate further rose to 6.66%, maintaining the same $500 million carrying amount. This upward trend in the effective rate indicates a shift in market conditions or internal risk assessments affecting the valuation of this long-term debt instrument over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [CSCO](2023) → [3.50% Note]: Carrying amount of $500 million and effective rate of 6.38%
Hop 2: [CSCO](2024) → [3.50% Note]: Carrying amount of $500 million and effective rate of 6.66%
Hop 3: [CSCO](2022) → [3.50% Note]: Carrying amount of $500 million and effective rate of 3.20%

questions.question: How did Cisco's financial exposure through Total Return Swaps-Deferred Compensation evolve from fiscal year 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's deferred compensation strategy and market-linked volatility?
questions.answer: Cisco's financial exposure tied to Total Return Swaps-Deferred Compensation shifted significantly across the three fiscal years: in 2022, the company recorded a loss of $92 million; in 2023, this turned into a gain of $58 million; and by 2024, the gain further increased to $91 million. This trajectory indicates a transformation from a net liability to a net benefit, suggesting either improved market conditions for the underlying assets or a strategic shift in how Cisco manages its deferred compensation obligations using these swaps.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [CSCO](2023) → Total Return Swaps-Deferred Compensation: Reports a gain of $58 million under operating expenses and other.
Hop 2: [CSCO](2024) → Total Return Swaps-Deferred Compensation: Records an increased gain of $91 million under operating expenses and other.
Hop 3: [CSCO](2022) → Total Return Swaps-Deferred Compensation: Reports a loss of $92 million under operating expenses and other.

questions.question: How did Cisco's utilization and effective interest rate of its 5.90% Note evolve from fiscal years 2022 through 2024, and what does this indicate about the company's long-term debt strategy and financing costs over this period?
questions.answer: Cisco consistently reported a $2,000 million outstanding balance for the 5.90% Note maturing in February 2039 across all three fiscal years (2022, 2023, and 2024), with the effective interest rate remaining constant at 6.11%. This stability in both principal and effective rate suggests that Cisco has maintained this long-term debt instrument without modification or refinancing over the three-year period, indicating a consistent approach to managing this portion of its capital structure despite broader changes in its debt portfolio.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [CSCO](2023) → [5.90% Note]: $2,000 million outstanding with 6.11% effective rate
Hop 2: [CSCO](2024) → [5.90% Note]: $2,000 million outstanding with 6.11% effective rate
Hop 3: [CSCO](2022) → [5.90% Note]: $2,000 million outstanding with 6.11% effective rate

questions.question: How did the financial performance of Cisco's available-for-sale (AFS) debt investments impact other income (loss), net across fiscal years 2022 through 2024, and what does this reveal about the volatility of its investment portfolio during this period?
questions.answer: In fiscal 2022, Cisco disclosed the composition and value of its AFS debt investments, indicating active portfolio management. By fiscal 2023, the company reported higher losses from these AFS debt investments, which negatively impacted its other income (loss), net. This trend continued into fiscal 2024, where AFS debt investment losses again contributed to a decline in other income (loss), net, despite offsetting gains from equity and private investments. The recurring negative impact from AFS debt investments over two consecutive years reveals a trend of increasing volatility in Cisco’s investment portfolio, particularly in its debt holdings, which has affected overall financial stability in non-operational income streams.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [CSCO](2023) → [AFS Debt Investments]: AFS debt investments caused higher losses, negatively impacting other income (loss), net.
Hop 2: [CSCO](2024) → [AFS Debt Investments]: AFS debt investment losses again contributed to a decline in other income (loss), net, despite gains elsewhere.
Hop 3: [CSCO](2022) → [AFS Debt Investments]: AFS debt investments were disclosed in detail, showing Cisco held a significant portfolio of such assets before the losses emerged.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
The	change	in	our	other	income	(loss),	net	was	primarily	driven	by	higher	losses	in	our	available-for-sale	debt	investments and	 unfavorable	 impacts	 from	 foreign	 exchange,	 partially	 offset	 by	 higher	 gains	 on	 our	 marketable	 equity	 investments	 and lower	net	losses	on	our	privately	held	investments.

## Provision	for	Income	Taxes

The	provision	for	income	taxes	resulted	in	an	effective	tax	rate	of	15.6%	for	fiscal	2024,	compared	with	17.7%	for	fiscal 2023.	 The	 net	 2.1	 percentage	 points	 decrease	 in	 the	 effective	 tax	 rate	 was	 primarily	 due	 to	 an	 increase	 in	 discrete	 tax benefits	relating	to	prior	year	return-to-provision	true	up	and	an	increase	in	stock-based	compensation	windfall	benefit.

For	a	full	reconciliation	of	our	effective	tax	rate	to	the	U.S.	federal	statutory	rate	of	21%	and	for	further	explanation	of our	provision	for	income	taxes,	see	Note	18	to	the	Consolidated	Financial	Statements.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
The change in our other income (loss), net was primarily driven by higher losses in our available-for-sale debt investments and unfavorable impacts from foreign exchange, partially offset by higher gains on our marketable equity investments and lower net losses on our privately held investments.

## Provision for Income Taxes

The provision for income taxes resulted in an effective tax rate of 15.6% for fiscal 2024, compared with 17.7% for fiscal 2023. The net 2.1 percentage points decrease in the  effective  tax   rate  was  primarily  due  to  an  increase  in  discrete  tax   benefits  relating  to  prior  year  return-to-provision  true  up  and  an  increase  in  stock-based compensation windfall benefit.

For a full reconciliation of our effective tax  rate to the U.S. federal statutory rate of 21% and for further ex planation of our provision for income tax es, see Note 18 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.

questions.question: How has Cisco's approach to pay equity evolved across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, particularly in relation to its commitment to the White House Equal Pay Pledge and the expansion of fairness metrics beyond base salary?
questions.answer: Cisco's approach to pay equity has evolved significantly from fiscal 2022 to 2024, with increasing transparency, broader inclusion of compensation components, and enhanced analytical rigor. In 2022, Cisco emphasized its status as a founding signer of the White House Equal Pay Pledge and its participation in the Employers for Pay Equity Consortium, using analytics to test for pay parity and correct gaps. By 2023, the company expanded its pay parity program beyond base salary to include promotions, bonuses, and stock decisions, integrating global self-reported diversity data into its analysis. In 2024, Cisco maintained this expanded framework and continued to highlight its commitment to fairness across all forms of compensation, while also reinforcing its broader diversity and inclusion initiatives, including a 36% female representation on the Executive Leadership Team as of July 2024. This progression shows a deepening and systematization of Cisco’s pay equity strategy over three years.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [CSCO](2023) → [White House Equal Pay Pledge]: Expanded pay parity program to include promotions, bonuses, and stock decisions, integrating global self-reported data.

Hop 2: [CSCO](2024) → [White House Equal Pay Pledge]: Continued emphasis on comprehensive pay fairness, supported by analytics and inclusion in broader diversity and inclusion reporting, including 36% female ELT representation.
Hop 3: [CSCO](2022) → [White House Equal Pay Pledge]: Identified as a founding signer and described use of analytics to test for pay parity, with a focus on correcting gaps when found.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

Cisco	has	signed	the	CEO	Action	for	Diversity	&	Inclusion	Pledge.	The	CEO	Action	for	Diversity	&	Inclusion	Pledge	is	a	CEOdriven	pledge	to	drive	measurable	action	and	meaningful	change	in	advancing	diversity,	equity	and	inclusion	in	the	workplace. We	are	delivering	on	these	actions	by	accelerating	diversity	across	the	full-spectrum	of	diversity	-	including	gender,	age, race,	 ethnicity,	 sexual	 orientation,	 ability,	 nationality,	 religion,	 veteran	 status,	 background,	 culture,	 experience, strengths	and	perspectives.	At	Cisco,	it	starts	at	the	top:	As	of	July	27,	2024,	36%	of	our	Executive	Leadership	Team	(ELT) are	women	and	43%	are	diverse	in	terms	of	gender	or	ethnicity.

We	publish	certain	gender	diversity	and	ethnic	diversity	workforce	data	annually.	Across	our	global	company,	we	have	driven broad	improvements	in	overall	workforce	diversity.	Based	on	our	fiscal	2023	data,	our	global	employee	base	was	comprised	of 29%	 women,	 71%	 men	 and	 0.1%	 nonbinary,	 and	 our	 U.S.	 employee	 base	 was	 comprised	 of	 the	 following	 ethnicities:	 48.2% White/Caucasian,	 33.5%	 Asian,	 6.5%	 Hispanic/Latino,	 5.6%	 African	 American/Black,	 2.0%	 two	 or	 more	 races	 (not	 Hispanic	 or Latino),	 0.3%	 American	 Indian	 or	 Alaska	 Native,	 0.2%	 Native	 Hawaiian/Other	 Pacific	 Islander,	 and	 3.7%	 prefer	 to	 not	 to disclose/unknown.

With	respect	to	social	justice,	Cisco	has	been	partnering	across	the	globe	to	scale	and	amplify	our	positive	impact.	We	have published	our	Social	Justice	Beliefs	&	Actions,	which	is	our	blueprint	for	how	we	respond	to	injustice	and	address	inequity for	any	community.	We	are	creating	actions	that	can	be	replicated	and	scaled	and	are	designed	to	cover	the	full	spectrum	of diversity,	inclusive	of	gender,	generation,	race,	ethnicity,	sexual	orientation,	ability,	nationality,	and	background	-	which is	the	foundation	of	our	Conscious	Culture.	This	work	is	part	of	a	plan	for	Cisco	to	drive	transformational,	generational impact	for	vulnerable	communities.	Our	Social	Justice	Action	Office	helps	drive	accountability,	progress,	and	excellence	in our	strategic	actions	in	this	area,	which	are	designed	to	address	the	broader	ecosystem	including	our	employees,	partners, customers,	and	suppliers.

## Compensation	and	Benefits

Our	 total	 compensation	 philosophy	 is	 designed	 to	 attract,	 reward,	 and	 retain	 talent.	 It	 provides	 market	 competitive, performance-based	compensation	aligned	with	each	employee's	contribution	and	impact	to	the	value	we	drive	to	our	customers, partners	and	stockholders.	We	reward	and	recognize	our	employees	for	effecting	innovation,	collaboration,	profitability,	and growth	within	our	geographies,	product	lines,	and	functions.

Cisco	has	always	been	committed	to	compensating	our	employees	fairly	and	equitably.	We	are	a	founding	signatory	of	the	White House	Equal	Pay	Pledge	and	the	Parity.org	pledge,	and	are	a	leader	in	the	charge	to	make	fair	pay	a	reality	for	all	employees through	the	Employers	for	Pay	Equity	Consortium.	We	have	also	introduced	an	innovative	and	inclusive	framework	that	provides us	powerful	analytics	to	evaluate	our	complex	compensation	system.	For	example,	by	using	these	powerful	analytics,	we	are able	to	test	for	pay	parity	on	a	regular	basis,	and	when	gaps	are	found,	we	strive	to	correct	them.

As	part	of	our	Social	Justice	Beliefs	and	Actions,	we	have	expanded	our	pay	parity	program	beyond	base	salary	to	include additional	forms	of	compensation	fairness	such	as	promotion,	bonuses,	and	stock	decisions	made	in	our	rewards	programs.	We aim	 to	 ensure	 the	 program	 addresses	 all	 employees	 across	 the	 full	 spectrum	 of	 diversity	 incorporating	 our	 global	 selfreported	data	collection.

## Health	&	Well-being

We	 have	 an	 ongoing	 commitment	 to	 focus	 on	 the	 health,	 safety,	 and	 well-being	 of	 our	 employees.	 We	 seek	 to	 provide	 our employees	and	their	families	with	high-quality,	flexible,	and	convenient	benefits	and	resources	for	their	physical,	mental, and	financial	well-being.	We	strive	to	support	our	employees	as	they	balance	careers	and	personal	lives,	as	well	as	their	own physical,	emotional,	and	financial	health.	We	continue	to	emphasize	a	focus	on	both	physical	and	mental	health,	recognizing the	need	to	create	an	environment	where	employees	can	speak	openly	about	mental	health	and	other	matters.

We	host	ongoing	discussions	with	our	employees	during	the	Cisco	Beat	and	Cisco	Check-Ins,	our	regular	company-wide	virtual meetings,	 and	 continue	 to	 emphasize	 our	 Safe	 to	 Talk	 program.	 We	 offer	 mindfulness	 courses,	 employee	 assistance	 program offerings,	and	out-of-network	provider	benefits	for	substance	abuse	and	mental	health	treatment,	and	more.	In	fiscal	2024,	we continued	to	offer	employees	'A	Day	for	Me,'	which	were	paid	days	off	that	allowed	for	each	individual	to	recharge	and	rest. We	employ	a	hybrid	work	model	in	certain	countries,	giving	our	employees	the	flexibility	to	work	offsite	or	at	onsite	Cisco locations.

## Employee	Development

We	know	careers	are	not	static	pathways	that	look	the	same	for	everyone.	We	also	know	that	the	world	of	work	will	continue	to rapidly	evolve,	requiring	new	skillsets.	At	Cisco,	we	believe	that	your	career	is	owned	by	you,	supported	by	your	leader,	and enabled	by	Cisco.	Cisco	believes	in	open-ended	self-directed	learning,	understanding	that	each	individual	knows	best	what skills	and	resources	they	need	to	succeed.	This	means	that	while	each	employee	has	the	power	to	shape	their	career	on	their own	 terms,	 they	 also	 have	 a	 supportive	 ecosystem	 to	 develop	 the	 skills	 they	 need	 to	 succeed	 both	 today	 and	 tomorrow.	 We strive	to
