questions.question: How did Adobe's strategic positioning and feature enhancements of Adobe Document Cloud evolve from 2022 to 2024, particularly in terms of integration with productivity tools, AI-driven workflows, and enterprise API services?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Adobe Document Cloud transitioned from being part of a broader legacy product suite to a more strategically highlighted cloud-based subscription offering with enhanced AI-driven features and enterprise integration capabilities. In 2022, Document Cloud was grouped under legacy offerings within a diverse set of products like eLearning, web conferencing, and Adobe Advertising Cloud, indicating a less differentiated role in Adobe’s portfolio. By 2023, Adobe began emphasizing Document Cloud as a core component of its Digital Media segment, alongside Creative Cloud, signaling a shift toward positioning it as a central productivity tool. In 2024, Adobe significantly expanded Document Cloud’s capabilities by integrating AI-powered workflows (e.g., Firefly generative AI features), introducing enterprise API services, and highlighting its integration with third-party productivity apps. This evolution reflects Adobe’s strategy to elevate Document Cloud from a supporting legacy product to a modern, AI-enhanced, and enterprise-ready platform.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [ADBE](2022) → [Adobe Document Cloud]: In 2022, Document Cloud was listed among legacy products within the Publishing and Advertising segment, grouped with eLearning, web conferencing, and Adobe Advertising Cloud, indicating a less prominent strategic role.

Hop 2: [ADBE](2024) → [Adobe Document Cloud]: In 2024, Document Cloud was described as a cloud-based subscription offering with AI-powered workflows (e.g., Firefly generative AI), enterprise API services, and integration across desktop, mobile, web, and third-party enterprise apps, showing a transformation into a modern productivity platform.

Hop 3: [ADBE](2023) → [Adobe Document Cloud]: In 2023, Adobe elevated Document Cloud as a core offering within the Digital Media segment, alongside Creative Cloud, signaling a strategic shift to position it as a key productivity tool for individuals and enterprises.

## Table of Contents

powered workflows. Firefly-powered generative AI features are also available in a number of our products including Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator, Adobe Express, Adobe Acrobat and Adobe Stock. Firefly is available for free with a limited number of G enerative Credits per month. Once that limit is reached, users and subscribers can buy additional Generative Credits through a Firefly paid subscription plan.

Also available for enterprises are Adobe Firefly Services and Custom Models. Firefly Services provides enterprises with APIs, tools and services for content generation, editing and assembly, to automate the production of content while maintaining quality and control. Custom Models enable enterprises to train generative AI models based on their intellectual property, product and brand styles across a wide variety of use cases such as localization or merchandising for e-commerce, maintaining and propagating brand consistency at scale across their organizations.

Adobe Firefly-generated content is designed to be commercially safe. The Firefly generative AI model is trained on data Adobe has the rights to use. Every asset created using Firefly includes Content Credentials, a digital 'nutrition label', to indicate that generative AI was used, bringing more trust and transparency to digital content.

## Adobe Stock

Adobe Stock provides designers and businesses with access to millions of high-quality, curated, royalty-free photos, vectors, illustrations, videos, templates, audio and 3D assets, for all their creative projects. Adobe Stock is built into our  Creative  Cloud Apps, including Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator, Adobe InDesign and Adobe Express, enabling users to search, browse and add assets to their Creative Cloud Libraries and instantly access them across all connected surfaces. Adobe Stock assets include free and paid collections and may be licensed directly within Adobe's Apps, through stock.adobe.com or as a multi-asset subscription.

## Frame.io

Frame.io is our cloud-native creative collaboration platform that streamlines the production of creative assets by enabling creative professionals and key project stakeholders to collaborate with real-time upload, review and approval, frame-accurate commenting, annotations and more. Frame.io includes support for video beyond post-production workflows including casting, location scouting, footage reviews, and marketing campaign management, as well as still images, design files and PDFs. Frame.io is directly integrated with Adobe Premiere Pro, Adobe After Effects, Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Lightroom and Adobe Workfront to allow video creators to request and receive streamlined frame-specific comments directly in those Apps.  Frame.io's  Camera to  Cloud functionality allows creators to automatically upload footage from cameras and other recording devices on set directly into Frame.io for review, with integrations for still image cameras that can connect natively to the platform. Frame.io, along with Adobe Express and Adobe Firefly Services, are available in Adobe G enStudio to enable content production at scale.

## Adobe Substance 3D Collection

Adobe Substance 3D is an ecosystem of desktop Apps, including Substance 3D Stager, Substance 3D Painter, Substance 3D Sampler, Substance 3D Designer and Substance 3D Modeler. Our customers can build and assemble 3D scenes with Stager, use tools in Painter to texture 3D assets, from advanced brushes to Smart Materials that automatically adapt to your model and use Sampler to digitize and enrich assets. Substance 3D Assets is a 3D materials library from which users can import professional quality 3D textures into their projects and generate infinite tex ture variations. Substance 3D Modeler, which is available on desktop and certain VR headsets, interprets spatial input from the physical world, allowing the user to sculpt a model as if in a real workshop, using natural, fluid gestures of the artistic flow, and switch between VR and desktop, at every project stage.

## Behance

Behance is a social community for creators to showcase and discover creative work online and live-stream their skills and creations from Creative Cloud Apps. Adobe Portfolio allows users to quickly and simply build a fully customizable and hosted website that seamlessly syncs with Behance.

## Adobe Document Cloud

Adobe Document Cloud is a cloud-based subscription offering that enables complete, reliable and automated digital document and signature workflows across desktop, mobile, web and third-party enterprise Apps to drive business productivity for individuals, teams, small businesses and enterprises. With Document Cloud, users can create, review, approve, sign and track documents and store them in the cloud for easy access and sharing across surfaces. Document Cloud includes Adobe Acrobat, Adobe Acrobat Sign, Adobe Scan and other Apps and API services that work standalone or integrate with users' existing productivity Apps, processes and systems.

## Forward-Looking	Statements

In	addition	to	historical	information,	this	Annual	Report	on	Form	10-K	contains	'forward-looking	statements,'	within	the meaning	 of	 applicable	 securities	 laws,	 including	 statements	 related	 to	 product	 development	 plans	 and	 new	 or	 enhanced offerings;	our	business,	artificial	intelligence	and	innovation	momentum;	our	vision	for	the	digital	world,	innovation	and AI;	 our	 market	 opportunity	 and	 future	 growth,	 market	 and	 AI	 trends,	 strategic	 investments;	 revenue,	 operating	 margin, operating	 efficiencies	 and	 annualized	 recurring	 revenue;	 industry	 positioning;	 and	 customer	 acquisition	 and	 retention.	 In addition,	when	used	in	this	report,	the	words	'will,'	'expects,'	'could,'	'would,'	'may,'	'anticipates,'	'intends,'	'plans,' 'believes,'	 'seeks,'	 'targets,'	 'estimates,'	 'looks	 for,'	 'looks	 to,'	 'continues'	 and	 similar	 expressions,	 as	 well	 as statements	regarding	our	focus	for	the	future,	are	generally	intended	to	identify	forward-looking	statements.	Each	of	the forward-looking	statements	we	make	in	this	report	are	based	on	information	available	to	us	as	of	the	date	of	this	report	and involves	risks,	uncertainties	and	assumptions	based	on	information	available	to	us	as	of	the	date	of	this	report.	Such	risks and	uncertainties,	many	of	which	relate	to	matters	beyond	our	control,	could	cause	actual	results	to	differ	materially	and adversely	from	these	forward-looking	statements.	Factors	that	might	cause	or	contribute	to	such	differences	include,	but	are not	limited	to,	those	discussed	in	the	section	titled	'Risk	Factors'	in	Part	I,	Item	1A	of	this	report	and	elsewhere	herein. The	 risks	 described	 herein	 and	 in	 Adobe's	 other	 filings	 with	 the	 U.S.	 Securities	 and	 Exchange	 Commission	 (the	 'SEC'), including	our	Quarterly	Reports	on	Form	10-Q	to	be	filed	in	fiscal	2024,	should	be	carefully	reviewed.	Undue	reliance	should not	be	placed	on	the	financial	information	set	forth	in	this	report,	which	reflects	estimates	based	on	information	available at	this	time.	Adobe	assumes	no	obligation	to,	and	does	not	currently	intend	to,	update	these	forward-looking	statements.

## PART	I

## ITEM	1.		BUSINESS

## OVERVIEW

Adobe	is	a	global	technology	company	with	a	mission	to	change	the	world	through	personalized	digital	experiences.	For over	four	decades,	Adobe's	innovations	have	transformed	how	individuals,	teams,	businesses,	enterprises,	institutions,	and governments	engage	and	interact	across	all	types	of	media.	Our	products,	services	and	solutions	are	used	around	the	world	to imagine,	create,	manage,	deliver,	measure,	optimize	and	engage	with	content	across	surfaces	and	fuel	digital	experiences.	We have	 a	 diverse	 user	 base	 that	 includes	 consumers,	 communicators,	 creative	 professionals,	 developers,	 students,	 small	 and medium	businesses	and	enterprises.	We	are	also	empowering	creators	by	putting	the	power	of	artificial	intelligence	('AI')	in their	hands,	and	doing	so	in	ways	we	believe	are	responsible.	Our	products	and	services	help	unleash	creativity,	accelerate document	productivity	and	power	businesses	in	a	digital	world.

## OFFERINGS

We	deliver	a	wide	range	of	products,	services	and	solutions	to	empower	our	customers	and	users	to	imagine	and	express ideas,	create	content	and	bring	any	digital	experience	to	life.	We	focus	our	strategic	investments	in	two	areas	of	growth:

Digital	Media. We	provide	products,	services	and	solutions	that	enable	individuals,	teams,	businesses	and	enterprises	to create,	publish	and	promote	their	content	anywhere,	and	accelerate	their	productivity	by	transforming	how	they	view,	share, engage	with	and	collaborate	on	documents	and	content	creation.	Our	Digital	Media	segment	is	centered	around	Adobe	Creative Cloud	and	Adobe	Document	Cloud,	which	include	Adobe	Express,	Adobe	Firefly,	Photoshop,	Illustrator,	Lightroom,	Premiere	Pro, Acrobat,	Acrobat	Sign	and	many	more	products,	offering	a	variety	of	tools	for	creative	professionals	(like	photographers, video	 editors	 and	 game	 developers),	 communicators	 and	 other	 consumers.	 This	 is	 the	 core	 of	 what	 we	 have	 delivered	 to customers	and	users	for	decades,	and	we	have	continually	evolved	and	expanded	our	Digital	Media	business	model	to	provide	our customers	and	users	with	a	range	of	flexible	solutions	to	help	them	reach	their	full	creative	potential.

Digital	 Experience. We	 provide	 an	 integrated	 platform	 and	 set	 of	 products,	 services	 and	 solutions	 through	 Adobe Experience	 Cloud	 that	 enable	 businesses	 to	 create,	 manage,	 execute,	 measure,	 monetize	 and	 optimize	 customer	 experiences spanning	 from	 analytics	 to	 commerce.	 Our	 customers	 include	 marketers,	 advertisers,	 agencies,	 publishers,	 merchandisers, merchants,	web	analysts,	data	scientists,	developers	and	executives	across	the	C-suite.	The	foundation	of	our	offering	is Adobe	Experience	Platform,	which	provides	businesses	and	brands	with	an	open	and	extensible	system	for	customer	experience management	that	transforms	customer	data	into	robust	customer	profiles	that	update	in	real	time	and	uses	insights	to	deliver personalized	digital	experiences	across	various	channels.

We	 offer	 a	 comprehensive	 suite	 of	 products,	 services	 and	 solutions	 to	 our	 customers	 and	 users	 in	 our	 Digital	 Media business	and	Digital	Experience	business.	In	addition,	our	Adobe	GenStudio	solution	bundles	together	certain	Digital	Media

questions.question: How has Adobe's positioning and integration of Frame.io evolved across 2022, 2023, and 2024, particularly in terms of its functional capabilities and integration depth with Adobe's Creative Cloud applications?
questions.answer: In 2022, Frame.io was listed as part of Adobe's trademark portfolio, indicating its acquisition and formal branding alignment. By 2023, Adobe detailed Frame.io's role as a cloud-native creative collaboration platform with real-time upload, review, and approval features, integrated with Premiere Pro and After Effects, and introduced support for still images, design files, and PDFs. In 2024, Adobe expanded Frame.io’s capabilities further, emphasizing its integration with Photoshop, Lightroom, and Workfront, and positioning it as a core component of Adobe GenStudio for enterprise-scale content production, alongside Firefly and Substance 3D tools. This progression shows a strategic deepening of Frame.io's functionality and its central role in Adobe's end-to-end creative workflow ecosystem.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [ADBE](2022) → [Frame.io]: Frame.io is listed among Adobe's trademarks, indicating formal branding and ownership post-acquisition.

Hop 2: [ADBE](2023) → [Frame.io]: Frame.io is described as a cloud-native collaboration platform with expanded support for still images, design files, and integration with Premiere Pro and After Effects.

Hop 3: [ADBE](2024) → [Frame.io]: Frame.io is positioned as a core enterprise collaboration tool, integrated with Photoshop, Lightroom, and Workfront, and included in Adobe GenStudio for large-scale content production.

Adobe Document Cloud is a cloud-based subscription offering that enables complete, reliable and automated digital document and signature workflows across desktop, mobile, web and third-party enterprise Apps to drive business productivity for individuals, teams, small businesses and enterprises. With Document Cloud, users can create, review, approve, sign and track documents and store them in the cloud for easy access and sharing across surfaces. Document Cloud includes Adobe Acrobat, Adobe Acrobat Sign, Adobe Scan and other Apps and API services that work standalone or integrate with users' existing productivity Apps, processes and systems.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

month.	 Once	 that	 limit	 is	 reached,	 users	 and	 subscribers	 can	 buy	 additional	 Generative	 Credits	 through	 a	 Firefly	 paid subscription	plan.

The	content	that	Adobe	Firefly	generates	is	designed	to	be	commercially	safe	because	the	Adobe	Firefly	generative	AI model	is	trained	on	licensed	content,	such	as	Adobe	Stock,	and	public	domain	content	for	which	copyright	has	expired.	Every asset	created	using	Adobe	Firefly	includes	Content	Credentials	to	indicate	that	generative	AI	was	used,	bringing	more	trust and	transparency	to	digital	content.	Content	Credentials	are	verifiable	details	that	serve	as	a	digital	'nutrition	label'	and can	show	information	including	an	asset's	name,	creation	date,	tools	used	for	creation	and	any	edits	made.

## Adobe	Stock

Adobe	 Stock	 provides	 designers	 and	 businesses	 with	 access	 to	 millions	 of	 high-quality,	 curated,	 royalty-free	 photos, vectors,	illustrations,	videos,	templates,	audio	and	3D	assets,	for	all	their	creative	projects.	Adobe	Stock	is	built	into our	Creative	Cloud	apps,	including	Photoshop,	Illustrator,	InDesign	and	Adobe	Express,	enabling	users	to	search,	browse	and add	 assets	 to	 their	 Creative	 Cloud	 Libraries	 and	 instantly	 access	 them	 across	 all	 connected	 surfaces.	 Adobe	 Stock	 assets include	free	and	paid	collections	and	may	be	licensed	directly	within	Adobe's	apps,	through	stock.adobe.com	or	as	a	multiasset	subscription.

## Frame.io

Frame.io	 is	 our	 cloud-native	 creative	 collaboration	 platform	 that	 streamlines	 the	 production	 of	 creative	 assets	 by enabling	 creative	 professionals	 and	 key	 project	 stakeholders	 to	 collaborate	 with	 real-time	 upload,	 review	 and	 approval, frame-accurate	 commenting,	 annotations	 and	 more-now	 with	 support	 for	 still	 images,	 design	 files	 and	 PDFs.	 Frame.io	 is directly	integrated	with	Premiere	Pro	and	After	Effects	to	allow	video	creators	to	request	and	receive	streamlined	framespecific	comments	directly	in	those	apps.	Frame.io's	Camera	to	Cloud	functionality	allows	creators	automatically	to	upload footage	from	cameras	and	other	recording	devices	on	set	directly	into	Frame.io	for	review,	with	integrations	with	still	image cameras	that	can	connect	natively	to	the	platform.

## Substance	3D	Collection

Substance	3D	is	an	ecosystem	of	desktop	apps,	including	Substance	3D	Stager,	Substance	3D	Painter,	Substance	3D	Sampler, Substance	3D	Designer	and	Substance	3D	Modeler.	Customers	can	build	and	assemble	3D	scenes	with	Stager,	use	tools	in	Painter to	texture	3D	assets,	from	advanced	brushes	to	Smart	Materials	that	automatically	adapt	to	your	model	and	use	Sampler	to digitize	and	enrich	assets.	Substance	3D	Assets	is	a	3D	materials	library	from	which	users	can	import	professional	quality	3D textures	into	their	projects	and	generate	infinite	texture	variations.	Substance	3D	Modeler,	which	is	available	on	desktop and	Meta	Quest	VR	headsets,	interprets	spatial	input	from	the	physical	world,	allowing	the	user	to	sculpt	a	model	as	if	in	a real	workshop,	using	natural,	fluid	gestures	of	the	artistic	flow,	and	switch	between	VR	and	desktop,	at	every	project	stage.

## Behance

Behance	is	a	social	community	for	creators	to	showcase	and	discover	creative	work	online	and	live-stream	their	skills	and creations	from	Creative	Cloud	apps.	Adobe	Portfolio	allows	users	to	quickly	and	simply	build	a	fully	customizable	and	hosted website	that	seamlessly	syncs	with	Behance.

## Adobe	Document	Cloud

Adobe	 Document	 Cloud	 is	 a	 cloud-based	 subscription	 offering	 that	 enables	 complete,	 reliable	 and	 automated	 digital document	and	signature	workflows	across	desktop,	mobile,	web	and	third-party	enterprise	apps	to	drive	business	productivity for	individuals,	teams,	small	businesses	and	enterprises.	With	Document	Cloud,	users	can	create,	review,	approve,	sign	and track	 documents	 and	 store	 them	 in	 the	 cloud	 for	 easy	 access	 and	 sharing	 across	 surfaces.	 Document	 Cloud	 includes	 Adobe Acrobat,	Acrobat	Sign,	Adobe	Scan	and	other	apps	and	API	services	that	work	standalone	or	integrate	with	users'	existing productivity	apps,	processes	and	systems.

All	 the	 apps	 listed	 below	 are	 available	 through	 a	 subscription	 to	 Adobe	 Acrobat.	 With	 the	 Acrobat	 Standard	 plan, subscribers	can	convert,	edit,	request	signatures,	and	protect	PDFs.	With	the	Acrobat	Pro	plan,	subscribers	have	full	convert and	 edit	 capabilities,	 advanced	 e-signature	 features	 including	 bulk	 send	 and	 custom	 branding,	 advanced	 protection,	 and additional	PDF	features.	We	also	offer	Adobe	Acrobat	subscription	plans	for	teams	and	enterprises.	Acrobat	Sign	is	included in	Adobe	Acrobat	subscriptions	for	individuals	and	teams.	Document	Cloud	for	enterprise	includes	Acrobat,	Acrobat	Sign,	and APIs	including	third-party	partner	integrations.	Adobe	Acrobat	Reader	and	Adobe	Scan	are	also	separately	available	as	free downloads.

questions.question: How did Microsoft's issuance of long-term debt instruments, specifically the 3.700% Notes due 2046, evolve across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this consistent inclusion reveal about the company's long-term capital strategy?
questions.answer: Microsoft's 3.700% Notes due 2046 were consistently referenced across all three fiscal years (2022, 2023, and 2024) as part of the company's Eleventh Supplemental Indenture dated August 8, 2016. The notes remained a stable component of Microsoft's long-term debt structure, indicating a consistent capital financing strategy focused on maintaining diversified and long-dated debt instruments to support strategic initiatives and financial flexibility.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MSFT](2022) → [3.700% Notes due 2046]: Microsoft references the Eleventh Supplemental Indenture dated August 8, 2016, which includes the 3.700% Notes due 2046 among other long-term debt instruments.

Hop 2: [MSFT](2023) → [3.700% Notes due 2046]: The 3.700% Notes due 2046 are again listed under the same Eleventh Supplemental Indenture dated August 8, 2016, showing no structural change in the debt instrument.

Hop 3: [MSFT](2024) → [3.700% Notes due 2046]: In the 2024 filing, the 3.700% Notes due 2046 continue to be listed under the same indenture, confirming sustained inclusion in Microsoft's long-term debt portfolio.

questions.question: How did Microsoft's issuance of 2.000% Notes due in 2023 evolve across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern indicate about the company's debt management strategy?
questions.answer: Microsoft consistently referenced the 2.000% Notes due 2023 in its filings across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating ongoing acknowledgment of this debt obligation. The Eleventh Supplemental Indenture related to these notes, dated August 8, 2016, was included in all three years' filings. This consistency suggests that Microsoft maintained its long-term debt structure without refinancing or retiring the 2.000% Notes due 2023 during this period, reflecting a stable approach to its fixed-income liabilities.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MSFT](2022) → [2.000% Notes due 2023]: Microsoft referenced the 2.000% Notes due 2023 in its 2022 10-K filing, specifically tied to the Eleventh Supplemental Indenture dated August 8, 2016.
Hop 2: [MSFT](2023) → [2.000% Notes due 2023]: In the 2023 10-K filing, Microsoft again referenced the 2.000% Notes due 2023 under the same Eleventh Supplemental Indenture dated August 8, 2016.

Hop 3: [MSFT](2024) → [2.000% Notes due 2023]: Microsoft continued to reference the 2.000% Notes due 2023 in its 2024 10-K filing, again citing the Eleventh Supplemental Indenture from August 8, 2016.

questions.question: How did Microsoft's disclosure of its 4.000% Notes due 2021 evolve across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings, and what does this consistency or change suggest about the company's long-term debt structure and refinancing strategy?
questions.answer: Microsoft's disclosure of the 4.000% Notes due 2021 remained consistent across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings, with the notes always appearing in the Third Supplemental Indenture (Exhibit 4.6) and linked to the original Indenture dated May 18, 2009. This consistency suggests that the company maintained the same legal and structural documentation for this debt instrument throughout the three-year period, indicating no material changes in its long-term debt obligations related to this issuance. The repeated inclusion of the same filing dates (e.g., 8-K filings on February 8, 2011) further supports that no refinancing or restructuring occurred for these notes during the observed timeframe.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MSFT](2022) → [4.000% Notes due 2021]: Disclosed in Exhibit 4.6 as part of the Third Supplemental Indenture dated February 8, 2011, incorporated under Form 8-K, indicating the structure and legal framework of the notes.
Hop 2: [MSFT](2023) → [4.000% Notes due 2021]: Repeated the same Exhibit 4.6 with identical descriptions and filing references, showing no modifications to the notes or their indenture.

Hop 3: [MSFT](2024) → [4.000% Notes due 2021]: Again included Exhibit 4.6 with unchanged details, confirming that the structure and documentation remained constant through the end of the observation period.

questions.question: How did Microsoft's treatment of the 3.950% Notes due 2056 across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings reflect its approach to long-term debt maturity management and refinancing strategy over time?
questions.answer: Microsoft consistently referenced the 3.950% Notes due 2056 in each of its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings as part of the Eleventh Supplemental Indenture dated August 8, 2016. The repeated inclusion of this long-term debt instrument across all three annual reports indicates that Microsoft maintained its commitment to this long-duration financing structure without modification or early redemption. This pattern suggests a deliberate strategy of preserving long-term capital stability by not altering or refinancing this specific tranche of debt, even as shorter-term instruments (e.g., 2.000% Notes due 2023 in 2022 filings and 2.400% Notes due 2026 in 2024) matured or approached maturity. The consistency in disclosure implies a strategic prioritization of long-dated liabilities to support long-term investment horizons, particularly during periods of evolving market interest rates.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MSFT](2022) → [3.950% Notes due 2056]: Microsoft referenced the Eleventh Supplemental Indenture dated August 8, 2016, which included the 3.950% Notes due 2056, indicating the long-term debt was active and disclosed in the capital structure.

Hop 2: [MSFT](2023) → [3.950% Notes due 2056]: The same Eleventh Supplemental Indenture was referenced in the 2023 filing, showing no change in the status of the 3.950% Notes due 2056, despite the maturity of other notes like the 2.000% Notes due 2023.

Hop 3: [MSFT](2024) → [3.950% Notes due 2056]: In the 2024 filing, the 3.950% Notes due 2056 remained part of the same Supplemental Indenture, with no indication of refinancing or redemption, even as newer notes like the 2.400% Notes due 2026 were highlighted.

questions.question: How did Microsoft's disclosure and treatment of its 2.125% Notes due 2021 evolve from fiscal years 2022 through 2024, and what does this imply about the company's debt management or refinancing strategy for this instrument?
questions.answer: Microsoft consistently referenced the 2.125% Notes due 2021 across its 10-K filings for fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating that the notes remained part of the company's active debt structure or disclosure obligations during this period despite their maturity in 2021. In the 2022 filing (MSFT_10k_2022.pdf, page 104), the notes were listed in Exhibit 4.10 under the Seventh Supplemental Indenture dated December 6, 2013. In 2023 (MSFT_10k_2023.pdf, page 104), the notes were again included in Exhibit 4.1 with the same indenture date. In 2024 (MSFT_10k_2024.pdf, page 104), the notes were still referenced in Exhibit 4.1, indicating no change in their documentation status. This persistence of reference may suggest either an extension or rollover of the instrument, continued disclosure requirements for historical instruments, or a lack of updated exhibit filings. The continued listing of a note that matured in 2021 raises questions about whether Microsoft refinanced the obligation or if there is a reporting lag in removing matured instruments from exhibit disclosures.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MSFT](2022) → [2.125% Notes due 2021]: Listed in Exhibit 4.10 under Seventh Supplemental Indenture dated December 6, 2013, indicating the notes were still part of active disclosures.
Hop 2: [MSFT](2023) → [2.125% Notes due 2021]: Reappeared in Exhibit 4.1 with the same indenture date, showing no structural change in the debt or its documentation.

Hop 3: [MSFT](2024) → [2.125% Notes due 2021]: Still referenced in Exhibit 4.1, suggesting either ongoing obligations, a delayed removal from disclosures, or a refinancing that did not alter the original indenture.

questions.question: As an investor analyzing Apple's capital structure, what does the consistent reference to Floating Rate Notes due 2019 in filings from 2022 through 2024 suggest about the company's long-term debt management and refinancing strategy?
questions.answer: Apple's consistent reference to Floating Rate Notes due 2019 across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 filings indicates a deliberate and stable approach to managing its long-term debt obligations. Despite the maturity of these notes in 2019, Apple continued to disclose them in its filings through 2024, suggesting that these instruments may have been part of a broader, ongoing debt structure or refinancing plan. This pattern implies that Apple may have rolled over or repriced this debt into newer instruments while maintaining transparency around its historical debt instruments, reflecting a disciplined and predictable capital structure strategy.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2022) → [Floating Rate Notes due 2019]: Listed in Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014 (Exhibit 4.4), showing continued disclosure of these notes in the 2022 filing despite their maturity in 2019.

Hop 2: [AAPL](2023) → [Floating Rate Notes due 2019]: Again referenced in the same Officer's Certificate (Exhibit 4.4) in the 2023 filing, indicating sustained inclusion in financial disclosures even after maturity.

Hop 3: [AAPL](2024) → [Floating Rate Notes due 2019]: Still included in the 2024 filing under Exhibit 4.4, demonstrating a consistent disclosure policy and possible integration into subsequent refinancing or capital structure planning.

questions.question: What does the consistent inclusion of the 0.45% Notes due 2016 in Apple's filings across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024 suggest about the company's long-term debt structure and disclosure strategy for legacy instruments?
questions.answer: Apple's 10-K filings for 2022, 2023, and 2024 all include Exhibit 4.3, which contains the Officer's Certificate dated May 3, 2013, detailing the 0.45% Notes due 2016 among other instruments. Despite the maturity of these notes in 2016, Apple continued to disclose this historical debt instrument across three consecutive annual reports. This pattern suggests that Apple maintains transparency around legacy debt structures, possibly to preserve a complete record of past financing activities for investor reference. The persistence of this disclosure, even after the notes' maturity, indicates a consistent approach to documenting capital structure history, rather than focusing solely on active obligations.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2022) → [0.45% Notes due 2016]: Included in Exhibit 4.3 as part of historical debt documentation
Hop 2: [AAPL](2023) → [0.45% Notes due 2016]: Continued disclosure of the same Officer's Certificate and note details despite maturity
Hop 3: [AAPL](2024) → [0.45% Notes due 2016]: Maintained inclusion of 0.45% Notes due 2016 in Exhibit 4.3, showing no change in disclosure approach

questions.question: How did Apple's issuance of long-term debt instruments, specifically the 4.45% Notes due 2044, evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern indicate about Apple's long-term capital strategy?
questions.answer: Apple consistently referenced the 4.45% Notes due 2044 in its filings across 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating a sustained reliance on long-term debt instruments as part of its capital structure. The repeated inclusion of the Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014, which includes the 4.45% Notes due 2044, across all three years shows that Apple maintained this long-term liability on its books without early redemption or restructuring during the observed period. This consistent presence suggests a strategic decision to retain long-duration debt, possibly to manage interest rate risk and maintain financial flexibility over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AAPL(2022) → 4.45% Notes due 2044: The 2022 10-K filing includes the Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014, which includes forms of global notes representing the 4.45% Notes due 2044.
Hop 2: AAPL(2023) → 4.45% Notes due 2044: The 2023 10-K filing also includes the same Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014, referencing the 4.45% Notes due 2044.
Hop 3: AAPL(2024) → 4.45% Notes due 2044: The 2024 10-K filing again includes the Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014, which includes the 4.45% Notes due 2044.

questions.question: How did Apple's disclosure regarding its 1.05% Notes due 2017 evolve across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings, and what does this continuity reveal about its approach to managing short-term debt instruments issued under its 2014 Officer's Certificate?
questions.answer: Apple's disclosure regarding the 1.05% Notes due 2017 remained unchanged across all three years — it was consistently described in the 10-K filings for 2022, 2023, and 2024 as part of the Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014. This static disclosure indicates that Apple did not modify or refinance this particular debt instrument during this period, suggesting a passive management approach toward this specific short-term debt obligation. The consistency in reporting implies that Apple prioritized stability in its capital structure for this instrument, choosing not to adjust its terms or maturity despite evolving market conditions.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2022) → [1.05% Notes due 2017]: Listed in the 2022 10-K filing as part of the May 6, 2014 Officer's Certificate with no modifications noted
Hop 2: [AAPL](2023) → [1.05% Notes due 2017]: Repeated verbatim in the 2023 10-K filing, showing no changes to the instrument or disclosure
Hop 3: [AAPL](2024) → [1.05% Notes due 2017]: Maintained unchanged in the 2024 10-K filing, confirming continued static treatment

questions.question: How did Apple's disclosure of its 2.40% Notes due 2023 evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern suggest about the company's long-term debt management strategy?
questions.answer: Apple first disclosed the 2.40% Notes due 2023 in its 2022 10-K filing as part of its Officer's Certificate dated May 3, 2013. The same disclosure was carried forward in both the 2023 and 2024 10-K filings, indicating no changes to the specific debt instrument's terms or status over the three-year period. This static disclosure suggests that Apple maintained a consistent approach to managing this particular debt obligation, with no early repayments, modifications, or extensions during the period. The lack of changes implies a stable long-term debt strategy for this instrument, with Apple likely planning to meet the 2023 maturity as originally structured.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2022) → [2.40% Notes due 2023]: Disclosed in Officer's Certificate dated May 3, 2013, as part of global notes structure
Hop 2: [AAPL](2023) → [2.40% Notes due 2023]: Repeated identical disclosure from May 3, 2013 Officer's Certificate without modification
Hop 3: [AAPL](2024) → [2.40% Notes due 2023]: Maintained identical disclosure language and structure from 2013 certificate, showing no changes through maturity year

questions.question: How did IBM's emphasis on client relationships and trust as a competitive differentiator evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this multi-year progression indicate about its strategic positioning in the hybrid cloud and AI market?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, IBM consistently emphasized client relationships and trust as a core competitive differentiator, but the context and strategic framing evolved. In 2022, IBM highlighted trust as part of its hybrid cloud and AI platform, emphasizing its ability to integrate data, AI, and industry expertise. In 2023, the company expanded this by linking trust to its strategic partnerships, showing how it leverages alliances to deliver end-to-end solutions. By 2024, IBM reinforced trust as a foundational element in its go-to-market strategy, particularly in addressing complex business challenges through a broad ecosystem of partners. This indicates a strategic deepening of how IBM positions trust not just as a value proposition, but as an enabler of integrated, client-centric innovation.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [IBM](2022) → [Client Relationships and Trust]: Emphasized as a competitive differentiator, tied to hybrid cloud and AI platform integration.
Hop 2: [IBM](2023) → [Client Relationships and Trust]: Positioned trust in the context of strategic partnerships, delivering end-to-end solutions.
Hop 3: [IBM](2024) → [Client Relationships and Trust]: Framed trust as foundational in go-to-market strategy and ecosystem collaboration.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## PART I

## Item 1. Business:

International Business Machines Corporation (IBM or the company) was incorporated in the State of New York on June 16, 1911, as the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Co. (C-T-R), a consolidation of the Computing Scale Co. of America, the Tabulating Machine Co. and The International Time Recording Co. of New York. Since that time, IBM has focused on the intersection of business insight and technological innovation, and its operations and aims have been international in nature. This was signaled almost 100 years ago, in 1924, when C-T-R changed its name to International Business Machines Corporation. And it continues today-we create sustained value for clients by helping them leverage the power of hybrid cloud and artificial intelligence (AI). Our hybrid cloud platform and AI technology support clients' digital transformations and helps them reimagine critical workflows, at scale, and modernize applications to increase agility, drive innovation and create operational efficiencies. Our offerings draw from leading IBM capabilities in software, consulting services capability to deliver business outcomes, and deep incumbency in mission-critical infrastructure, all bolstered by one of the world's leading research organizations.

The following information is included in IBM's 2021 Annual Report to Stockholders and is incorporated by reference:

IBM Strategy-pages 11 to 13.

Business Segments and Capabilities-pages 13 to 15.

Human Capital-pages 15 to 16.

## Competition

IBM is a globally integrated enterprise that participates in a highly competitive environment, where our competitors vary by industry segment, and range from large multinational enterprises to smaller, more narrowly focused entities. Overall, across our business segments, we recognize hundreds of competitors worldwide.

Our principal methods of competition are: technology innovation; performance; price; quality; brand; our broad range of capabilities, products and services; talent; client relationships and trust; the ability to deliver business value to clients; and service and support. In order to maintain leadership, we are optimizing our portfolio with organic and inorganic innovations, shifting resources, embedding AI and cloud into our offerings while building new solutions and modernizing our existing platforms. These investments not only drive current performance, but will extend our innovation leadership into the future.

We differentiate from other providers, as our breadth and depth of expertise enables us to take different technologies and bring them together to solve the most pressing business issues of our clients. We leverage a flexible, secure, and open hybrid cloud platform and scale up solutions integrating (1) data, (2) AI for production and automation, (3) deep expertise in industries and business processes, (4) trust and security, along with (5) a broad ecosystem of partners and alliances. All of these actions have positioned IBM for accelerated growth now with hybrid cloud and AI while preparing us for the next set of business opportunities, such as quantum computing.

As we execute our strategy as a hybrid cloud and AI company, we are regularly exposed to new competitors. Overall, the company is the leader or among the leaders in each of our business segments.

A summary of the competitive environment for each business segment is included below:

## Software:

The depth, breadth, and innovation of our software offerings, coupled with our global reach, deep industry expertise and research capabilities help differentiate our offerings from our competitors. Our hybrid cloud platform based on open

## Table	of	Contents

## PART	I

## Item	1.	Business:

International	Business	Machines	Corporation	(IBM	or	the	company)	was	incorporated	in	the	State	of	New	York	on	June	16, 1911,	as	the	Computing-Tabulating-Recording	Co.	(C-T-R),	a	consolidation	of	the	Computing	Scale	Co.	of	America,	the Tabulating	Machine	Co.	and	The	International	Time	Recording	Co.	of	New	York.	Since	that	time,	IBM	has	focused	on	the intersection	of	business	insight	and	technological	innovation,	and	its	operations	and	aims	have	been	international	in	nature. This	was	signaled	100	years	ago,	in	1924,	when	C-T-R	changed	its	name	to	International	Business	Machines	Corporation.	And	it continues	today-we	create	sustained	value	for	clients	by	helping	them	leverage	the	power	of	hybrid	cloud	and	artificial intelligence	(AI).	Our	hybrid	cloud	platform	and	AI	technology	support	clients'	digital	transformations	and	helps	them reimagine	critical	workflows,	at	scale,	and	modernize	applications	to	increase	agility,	drive	innovation	and	create operational	efficiencies.	Our	offerings	draw	from	leading	IBM	capabilities	in	software,	consulting	services	capability	to deliver	business	outcomes,	and	deep	incumbency	in	mission-critical	infrastructure,	all	bolstered	by	one	of	the	world's leading	research	organizations.

The	following	information	is	included	in	IBM's	2023	Annual	Report	to	Stockholders	and	is	incorporated	by	reference:

IBM	Strategy-pages	11	to	13.

Business	Segments	and	Capabilities-pages	13	to	15.

Human	Capital-pages	15	to	16.

## Strategic	Partnerships

We	proactively	partner	with	a	broad	variety	of	companies	including	hyperscalers,	service	providers,	global	system integrators,	and	software	and	hardware	vendors.	We	work	alongside	our	partners	to	deliver	end-to-end	solutions	that	address our	clients'	complex	business	challenges	while	accelerating	growth.	Our	strategic	partners	include:	Adobe,	Amazon	Web Services	(AWS),	Microsoft,	Oracle,	Salesforce,	Samsung	Electronics	and	SAP,	among	others.

Companies	with	which	we	have	strategic	partnerships	in	some	areas	may	be	competitors	in	other	areas.

## Competition

IBM	is	a	globally	integrated	enterprise	that	participates	in	a	highly	competitive	environment.	Our	competitors	vary	by industry	segment,	and	range	from	large	multinational	enterprises	to	smaller,	more	narrowly	focused	entities.	Across	our business	segments,	we	recognize	hundreds	of	competitors	worldwide	and	as	we	execute	our	hybrid	cloud	and	AI	strategy,	we	are regularly	exposed	to	new	competitors.

Our	principal	methods	of	competition	are:	technology	innovation;	performance;	price;	quality;	brand;	our	breadth	of capabilities,	products	and	services;	talent;	client	relationships	and	trust;	the	ability	to	deliver	business	value	to clients;	and	service	and	support.	In	order	to	maintain	leadership,	we	optimize	our	portfolio	with	organic	and	inorganic innovations	and	effective	resource	allocation.	These	investments	not	only	drive	current	performance	but	will	extend	our innovation	leadership	into	the	future.

Our	breadth	and	depth	of	expertise	enables	us	to	take	different	technologies	and	bring	them	together	to	solve	the	most pressing	business	issues	of	our	clients.	We	differentiate	from	other	providers	by	bringing	together	incumbency	with enterprises,	deep	expertise	in	technology,	industries	and	business	processes,	a	broad	go-to-market	reach	including	an ecosystem	of	partners	and	alliances,	and	a	strong	focus	on	innovation.	All	of	these	attributes	position	IBM	for	accelerated growth	now	and	prepare	us	for	the	next	set	of	business	opportunities,	such	as	quantum	computing.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## PART I

## Item 1. Business:

International Business Machines Corporation (IBM or the company) was incorporated in the State of New York on June 16, 1911, as the Computing-TabulatingRecording Co. (C-T-R), a consolidation of the Computing Scale Co. of America, the Tabulating Machine Co. and The International Time Recording Co. of New York. Since that time, IBM has focused on the intersection of business insight and technological innovation, and its operations and aims have been international in nature. This was signaled over 100 years ago, in 1924, when C-T-R changed its name to International Business Machines Corporation. And it continues today-we create sustained value for clients by helping them leverage the power of hybrid cloud and artificial intelligence (AI). Our hybrid cloud platform and AI technology support clients' digital transformations and helps them reimagine critical workflows, at scale, and modernize applications to increase agility, drive innovation and create operational efficiencies. Our offerings draw from leading IBM capabilities in software, consulting services capability to deliver business outcomes, and deep incumbency in mission-critical infrastructure, all bolstered by one of the world's leading research organizations.

The following information is included in IBM's 2024 Annual Report to Stockholders and is incorporated by reference:

IBM Strategy-pages 11 to 12.

Business Segments and Capabilities-pages 12 to 14.

Human Capital-pages 14 to 15.

## Strategic Partnerships

We proactively partner with a broad variety of companies including hyperscalers, service providers, global system integrators, and software and hardware vendors. We work alongside our partners to deliver end-to-end solutions that address our clients' complex business challenges while accelerating growth. Our strategic partners include: Adobe, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft, Oracle, Palo Alto Networks, Salesforce, Samsung Electronics and SAP, among others.

Companies with which we have strategic partnerships in some areas may be competitors in other areas.

## Competition

IBM is a globally integrated enterprise that participates in a highly competitive environment. Our competitors vary by industry segment, and range from large multinational enterprises to smaller, more narrowly focused entities. Across our business segments, we recognize hundreds of competitors worldwide and as we execute our hybrid cloud and AI strategy, we are regularly exposed to new competitors.

Our principal methods of competition are: technology innovation; performance; price; quality; brand; our breadth of capabilities, products and services; talent; client relationships and trust; the ability to deliver business value to clients; and service and support. In order to maintain leadership, we optimize our portfolio with organic and inorganic innovations and effective resource allocation. These investments not only drive current performance but will extend our innovation leadership into the future.

Our breadth and depth of expertise enables us to take different technologies and bring them together to solve the most pressing business issues of our clients. We differentiate from other providers by bringing together incumbency with enterprises, deep expertise in technology, industries and business processes, a broad go-to-market reach including an ecosystem of partners and alliances, and a strong focus on innovation. All of these attributes position IBM for accelerated growth now and prepare us for the next set of business opportunities, such as quantum computing.

questions.question: How has IBM's treatment of its 1.250% Notes due 2027 evolved from 2022 to 2024, particularly in terms of disclosure practices and the instrument's role within the company's debt portfolio?
questions.answer: In 2022, IBM referenced the 1.250% Notes due 2027 in its exhibit list as part of a broader set of instruments, specifically noting that the rights of holders were defined in Exhibit 4.3 to Form 8-K filed January 30, 2019. By 2023, the Notes were again referenced in a list that included a growing number of debt instruments, now tied to more recent filings such as February 8, 2022, indicating a broader and more complex debt structure. In 2024, the 1.250% Notes due 2027 were explicitly listed in the company's 10-K with a distinct trading symbol (IBM27B), showing they had become a formally recognized and actively traded financial instrument. This progression reflects IBM's increasing transparency and emphasis on this particular note within its capital structure.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: IBM(2022) → 1.250% Notes due 2027: The instrument is referenced in Exhibit 4.3 to Form 8-K filed January 30, 2019, as defining the rights of holders.

Hop 2: IBM(2023) → 1.250% Notes due 2027: The instrument is again referenced, this time among a more extensive set of notes, including those filed as recently as February 8, 2022, indicating a growing and more complex debt portfolio.

Hop 3: IBM(2024) → 1.250% Notes due 2027: The Notes are explicitly listed in the 10-K with a distinct trading symbol (IBM27B), confirming their status as a recognized and actively traded financial instrument.

questions.question: How did IBM's disclosures around the 6.50% Debentures due 2028 evolve from 2022 to 2024, particularly in relation to the consistency of exhibit references and the broader context of IBM's debt instrument disclosures?
questions.answer: IBM consistently referenced the 6.50% Debentures due 2028 as Exhibit 2 to Form 8-K, filed on January 8, 1998, across all three years (2022, 2023, and 2024), indicating no changes in the documentation defining the rights of the holders of these debentures. However, the broader context of IBM's debt disclosures evolved subtly over time. In 2022, the debentures were listed among a wider range of debt instruments, including newer notes due in 2022, 2023, 2024, and beyond, with detailed exhibit references for each. By 2023 and 2024, the disclosures focused more on integrating legacy debt (like the 6.50% Debentures due 2028) alongside newer instruments such as the 6.22% Debentures due 2027 and 5.875% Debentures due 2032, suggesting a continued emphasis on long-term debt management and investor clarity. This consistency in exhibit referencing for the 6.50% Debentures due 2028, despite the broader evolution in debt disclosures, likely supports regulatory compliance and investor understanding of IBM's long-standing obligations.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [IBM](2022) → [6.50% Debentures due 2028]: Discloses the instrument defining the rights of the holders as Exhibit 2 to Form 8-K, filed on January 8, 1998, alongside a broader set of debt instruments with specific exhibit references.

Hop 2: [IBM](2023) → [6.50% Debentures due 2028]: Reiterates the same Exhibit 2 to Form 8-K, filed on January 8, 1998, as the instrument defining the rights of the holders, while also including newer debt instruments such as the 6.22% Debentures due 2027.

Hop 3: [IBM](2024) → [6.50% Debentures due 2028]: Maintains the same exhibit reference (Exhibit 2 to Form 8-K, filed on January 8, 1998) for the 6.50% Debentures due 2028, and continues to integrate this legacy debt with newer instruments like the 5.875% Debentures due 2032.

questions.question: How did IBM's 0.950% Notes due 2025 transition from a disclosed obligation to a publicly traded financial instrument between 2022 and 2024?
questions.answer: In 2022, IBM disclosed the existence of the 0.950% Notes due 2025 as part of its long-term debt obligations in its 10-K filing, referencing the instruments defining the rights of the holders through Exhibit 4.1 to Form 8-K filed on May 22, 2017. In 2023, IBM reaffirmed the ongoing relevance of these notes by reiterating their inclusion in the company's debt structure, again citing the same filing (May 22, 2017) as the source of the instrument defining holders' rights. By 2024, the 0.950% Notes due 2025 had transitioned from being a disclosed obligation to a publicly traded instrument, as evidenced by its listing on the New York Stock Exchange under the trading symbol IBM25B. This progression illustrates IBM’s strategic movement from internal documentation and disclosure to active capital market engagement with this debt instrument.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: IBM(2022) → 0.950% Notes due 2025: Discloses the notes as part of its debt obligations with reference to Exhibit 4.1 (Form 8-K, May 22, 2017).
Hop 2: IBM(2023) → 0.950% Notes due 2025: Reaffirms the notes’ existence and legal framework by re-citing the same May 22, 2017 filing.
Hop 3: IBM(2024) → 0.950% Notes due 2025: The notes are now listed as publicly traded instruments on the NYSE under the symbol IBM25B.

questions.question: How did IBM's exposure to stock exchange regulations evolve across 2022, 2023, and 2024, particularly in relation to its debt and equity securities, and what does this multi-year progression reveal about its capital market risk management strategy?
questions.answer: In 2022, IBM highlighted that its debt and equity securities were subject to fluctuations influenced by stock exchange regulations, among other external factors, with no direct control over these risks. In 2023, the company reiterated similar exposure, particularly emphasizing the impact of regulatory and exchange controls on debt securities and the volatility of common stock prices due to speculative and geopolitical factors. By 2024, IBM expanded on this by detailing how stock exchange regulations were part of a broader set of capital market risks, including liquidity conditions, credit risk on receivables, and pension-related financial pressures. The consistent framing of regulatory exposure across all three years suggests a stable risk profile, but the growing contextual complexity — especially in 2024 — indicates a more nuanced articulation of regulatory impact amid broader macroeconomic pressures.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: IBM (2022) → Stock Exchange Regulations: Discloses that debt and equity securities are subject to stock exchange regulations and other external factors, with no direct control over these risks.

Hop 2: IBM (2023) → Stock Exchange Regulations: Reiterates exposure to stock exchange regulations as part of capital market risks, with added emphasis on speculative and geopolitical volatility affecting stock prices.

Hop 3: IBM (2024) → Stock Exchange Regulations: Expands the regulatory risk narrative to include liquidity conditions, credit risk on receivables, and pension-related financial pressures, embedding stock exchange regulations within a broader capital market risk framework.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## Risks Related to Ownership of IBM Securities

Risk Factors Related to IBM Securities: The company and its subsidiaries issue debt securities in the worldwide capital markets from time to time, with a variety of different maturities and in different currencies. The value of the company's debt securities fluctuates based on many factors, including the methods employed for calculating principal and interest, the maturity of the securities, the aggregate principal amount of securities outstanding, the redemption features for the securities, the level, direction and volatility of interest rates, changes in exchange rates, exchange controls, governmental and stock exchange regulations and other factors over which the company has little or no control. The company's ability to pay interest and repay the principal for its debt securities is dependent upon its ability to manage its business operations, as well as the other risks described under this Item 1A. entitled 'Risk Factors.' There can be no assurance that the company will be able to manage any of these risks successfully.

The company also issues its common stock from time to time in connection with various compensation plans, contributions to its pension plan and certain acquisitions. The market price of IBM common stock is subject to significant volatility, due to other factors described under this Item 1A. entitled 'Risk Factors,' as well as economic and geopolitical conditions generally, trading volumes, speculation by the press or investment community about the company's financial condition, and other factors, many of which are beyond the company's control. Since the market price of IBM's common stock fluctuates significantly, stockholders may not be able to sell the company's stock at attractive prices.

In addition, changes by any rating agency to the company's outlook or credit ratings can negatively impact the value and liquidity of both the company's debt and equity securities. The company does not make a market in either its debt or equity securities and cannot provide any assurances with respect to the liquidity or value of such securities.

## Item 1B. Unresolved Staff Comments:

Not applicable.

## Item 2. Properties:

IBM's corporate headquarters are located at an owned site in Armonk, New York. As of December 31, 2021, in aggregate, we owned or leased facilities for current use consisting of approximately 52 million square feet worldwide.

At December 31, 2021, IBM's facilities in the U.S. had aggregate floor space of approximately 20 million square feet, of which approximately 9 million was owned and 11 million was leased. Outside the U.S., facilities totaled nearly 32 million square feet, of which 7 million was owned and 25 million was leased. This space is primarily used for sales and distribution, manufacturing and development, data processing services including the company's cloud centers, research and other administrative and general support purposes. Our facilities are utilized for current operations of all business segments.

Continuous maintenance and upgrading of facilities are essential to maintain technological leadership, improve productivity and meet customer demand. We believe that in all material respects our properties have been satisfactorily maintained, are in good condition and are suitable for our operations.

## Item 3. Legal Proceedings:

Refer to note S, 'Commitments & Contingencies,' on pages 113 to 115 of IBM's 2021 Annual Report to Stockholders, which is incorporated herein by reference.

## Item 4. Mine Safety Disclosures:

Not applicable.

## Table	of	Contents

the	company's	sales	are	on	an	open	credit	basis,	and	the	company	performs	ongoing	credit	evaluations	of	its	clients' financial	conditions.	If	the	company	becomes	aware	of	information	related	to	the	creditworthiness	of	a	major	customer,	or	if future	actual	default	rates	on	receivables	in	general	differ	from	those	currently	anticipated,	the	company	may	have	to	adjust its	allowance	for	credit	losses,	which	could	affect	the	company's	consolidated	net	income	in	the	period	the	adjustments	are made.

## Risks	Related	to	the	Spin-Off	of	Kyndryl	Holdings,	Inc.

If	the	Kyndryl	Holdings,	Inc.	Spin-off	Fails	to	Qualify	for	Tax-free	Treatment,	It	Could	Result	in	Substantial	Tax Liability	for	the	Company	and	Its	Stockholders: In	connection	with	the	spin-off	of	Kyndryl	Holdings,	Inc.,	the	company obtained	a	private	letter	ruling	from	the	IRS	and	an	opinion	from	its	tax	advisor,	in	each	case	to	the	effect	that,	for	U.S. federal	income	tax	purposes,	the	spin-off	will	qualify	as	a	tax-free	reorganization	under	sections	368(a)(1)(D)	and	355	of the	Internal	Revenue	Code	of	1986,	as	amended.	The	IRS	private	letter	ruling	and	the	opinion	rely	on	certain	facts, assumptions,	representations	and	undertakings	from	Kyndryl	Holdings,	Inc.	and	the	company	regarding	the	past	and	future conduct	of	the	companies'	respective	businesses	and	other	matters.	If	any	of	these	facts,	assumptions,	representations,	or undertakings	are	incorrect	or	not	satisfied,	the	conclusions	reached	in	the	IRS	private	letter	ruling	and/or	the	opinion could	be	jeopardized.	If	the	spin-off	is	determined	to	be	taxable	for	U.S.	federal	income	tax	purposes,	the	company's stockholders	that	are	subject	to	U.S.	federal	income	tax	and	the	company	could	incur	significant	U.S.	federal	income	tax liabilities.

## Risks	Related	to	Ownership	of	IBM	Securities

Risk	Factors	Related	to	IBM	Securities: The	company	and	its	subsidiaries	issue	debt	securities	in	the	worldwide	capital markets	from	time	to	time,	with	a	variety	of	different	maturities	and	in	different	currencies.	The	value	of	the	company's debt	securities	fluctuates	based	on	many	factors,	including	the	methods	employed	for	calculating	principal	and	interest,	the maturity	of	the	securities,	the	aggregate	principal	amount	of	securities	outstanding,	the	redemption	features	for	the securities,	the	level,	direction	and	volatility	of	interest	rates,	changes	in	exchange	rates,	exchange	controls,	governmental and	stock	exchange	regulations	and	other	factors	over	which	the	company	has	little	or	no	control.	The	company's	ability	to pay	interest	and	repay	the	principal	for	its	debt	securities	is	dependent	upon	its	ability	to	manage	its	business	operations, as	well	as	the	other	risks	described	under	this	Item	1A.	entitled	'Risk	Factors.'	There	can	be	no	assurance	that	the	company will	be	able	to	manage	any	of	these	risks	successfully.

The	company	also	issues	its	common	stock	from	time	to	time	in	connection	with	various	compensation	plans,	contributions	to its	pension	plan	and	certain	acquisitions.	The	market	price	of	IBM	common	stock	is	subject	to	significant	volatility,	due	to other	factors	described	under	this	Item	1A.	entitled	'Risk	Factors,'	as	well	as	economic	and	geopolitical	conditions generally,	trading	volumes,	speculation	by	the	press	or	investment	community	about	the	company's	financial	condition,	and other	factors,	many	of	which	are	beyond	the	company's	control.	Since	the	market	price	of	IBM's	common	stock	fluctuates significantly,	stockholders	may	not	be	able	to	sell	the	company's	stock	at	attractive	prices.

In	addition,	changes	by	any	rating	agency	to	the	company's	outlook	or	credit	ratings	can	negatively	impact	the	value	and liquidity	of	both	the	company's	debt	and	equity	securities.	The	company	does	not	make	a	market	in	either	its	debt	or	equity securities	and	cannot	provide	any	assurances	with	respect	to	the	liquidity	or	value	of	such	securities.

## Item	1B.	Unresolved	Staff	Comments:

Not	applicable.

## Item	1C.	Cybersecurity:

## Risk	Management	and	Strategy

Cybersecurity	is	a	critical	part	of	risk	management	at	IBM	and	is	integrated	with	the	company's	overall	enterprise	risk management	framework.	The	Board	of	Directors	and	the	Audit	Committee	of	the	Board	are	responsible	for	overseeing	management's execution	of	cybersecurity	risk	management	and	for	assessing	IBM's	approach	to	risk	management.	Senior	management	is responsible	for	assessing	and	managing	IBM's	exposure	to	cybersecurity	risks	on	an	ongoing	basis.

From	an	enterprise	perspective,	we	implement	a	multi-faceted	risk	management	approach	based	on	the	National	Institute	of Standards	and	Technology	Cybersecurity	Framework.	We	have	established	policies	and	procedures	that	provide

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## Risks Related to Financing and Capital Markets Activities

The Company's Results of Operations and Financial Condition Could Be Negatively Impacted by Its U.S. and non-U.S. Pension Plans: Adverse financial market conditions and volatility in the credit markets may have an unfavorable impact on the value of the company's pension trust assets and its future estimated pension liabilities. As a result, the company's financial results in any period could be negatively impacted. In addition, in a period of an ex tended financial market downturn, the company could be required to provide incremental pension plan funding with resulting liquidity risk which could negatively impact the company's financial flex ibility. Further, the company's results could be negatively impacted by premiums for mandatory pension insolvency insurance coverage outside the United States. Premium increases could be significant due to the level of insolvencies of unrelated companies in the country at issue. IBM's 2024 Annual Report to Stockholders includes information about potential impacts from pension funding and the use of certain assumptions regarding pension matters.

The Company Is Exposed to Currency and Financing Risks That Could Impact Its Revenue and Business: The company derives a significant percentage of its revenues and costs from its affiliates operating in local currency environments, and those results are affected by changes in the relative values of non-U.S. currencies and the U.S. dollar, as well as sudden shifts in regional or global economic activity. Further, inherent in the company's financing business are risks related to the concentration of credit, client creditworthiness, interest rate and currency fluctuations on the associated debt and liabilities and the determination of residual values. The company employs a number of strategies to manage these risks, including the use of derivative financial instruments, which involve the risk of non-performance by the counterparty. In addition, there can be no assurance that the company's efforts to manage its currency and financing risks will be successful.

The Company's Financial Performance Could Be Impacted by Changes in Market Liquidity Conditions and by Customer Credit Risk on Receivables: The company's financial performance is exposed to a wide variety of industry sector dynamics worldwide, including sudden shifts in regional or global economic activity. The company's earnings and cash flows, as well as its access to funding, could be negatively impacted by changes in market liquidity conditions. IBM's 2024 Annual Report to Stockholders includes information about the company's liquidity position. The company's client base includes many enterprises worldwide, from small and medium businesses to the world's largest organizations and governments, with a significant portion of the company's revenue coming from global clients across many sectors. Most of the company's sales are on an open credit basis, and the company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its clients' financial conditions. If the company becomes aware of information related to the creditworthiness of a major customer, or if future actual default rates on receivables in general differ from those currently anticipated, the company may have to adjust its allowance for credit losses, which could affect the company's consolidated net income in the period the adjustments are made.

## Risks Related to Ownership of IBM Securities

Risk Factors Related to IBM Securities: The company and its subsidiaries issue debt securities in the worldwide capital markets from time to time, with a variety of different maturities and in different currencies. The value of the company's debt securities fluctuates based on many factors, including the methods employed for calculating principal and interest, the maturity of the securities, the aggregate principal amount of securities outstanding, the redemption features for the securities, the level, direction and volatility of interest rates, changes in ex change rates, ex change controls, governmental and stock ex change regulations and other factors over which the company has little or no control. The company's ability to pay interest and repay the principal for its debt securities is dependent upon its ability to manage its business operations, as well as the other risks described under this Item 1A. entitled 'Risk Factors.' There can be no assurance that the company will be able to manage any of these risks successfully.

The company also issues its common stock from time to time in connection with various compensation plans, contributions to its pension plan and certain acquisitions. The market price of IBM common stock is subject to significant volatility, due to other factors described under this Item 1A. entitled 'Risk Factors,' as well as economic and geopolitical conditions generally, trading volumes, speculation by the press or investment community about the company's financial condition, and other factors, many of which are beyond the company's control. Since the market price of IBM's common stock fluctuates significantly, stockholders may not be able to sell the company's stock at attractive prices.

In addition, changes by any rating agency to the company's outlook or credit ratings can negatively impact the value and liquidity of both the company's debt and equity securities. The company does not make a market in either its debt or equity securities and cannot provide any assurances with respect to the liquidity or value of such securities.

questions.question: How did Apple's continued inclusion of Floating Rate Notes due 2019 in its debt disclosures from 2022 through 2024 reflect its approach to short-term interest rate risk management and liquidity planning?
questions.answer: Apple consistently included Floating Rate Notes due 2019 in its debt disclosures across all three years (2022, 2023, and 2024), indicating a deliberate and stable approach to managing short-term interest rate risk. The recurring appearance of these notes in the 10-K filings suggests that Apple maintained exposure to variable interest rates through these instruments, likely to align borrowing costs with current market conditions. This consistency implies that Apple's liquidity planning strategy relied on flexible debt instruments that could adapt to changing interest rate environments, without needing to issue new short-term floating rate instruments during this period. The company's approach reflects a cautious yet adaptive stance toward financing operations and capital returns while managing exposure to interest rate volatility.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2023) → Floating Rate Notes due 2019: Disclosed in Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014, as part of Exhibit 4.4, indicating continued recognition of these notes in financial reporting.

Hop 2: [AAPL](2024) → Floating Rate Notes due 2019: Again referenced in the 2024 10-K filing under Exhibit 4.4, showing sustained acknowledgment of these notes in Apple's capital structure despite the due date having passed, possibly indicating rollover or extended disclosure requirements.

Hop 3: [AAPL](2022) → Floating Rate Notes due 2019: Explicitly listed in the 2022 10-K filing under Exhibit 4.4, confirming that Apple maintained visibility and disclosure continuity for these notes well after their maturity, suggesting strategic or compliance significance.

questions.question: How did Apple's issuance of the 0.45% Notes due 2016 evolve across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this pattern reveal about the company's long-term debt structuring strategy?
questions.answer: Apple first disclosed the 0.45% Notes due 2016 in its 2022 10-K filing as part of a broader set of global notes issued under an Officer's Certificate dated May 3, 2013. The same disclosure was repeated in both the 2023 and 2024 10-K filings, indicating that the company maintained this debt instrument as part of its capital structure across all three years. The consistent inclusion of the 0.45% Notes due 2016 in each annual report suggests a stable long-term debt strategy, with Apple preserving a mix of older, lower-yield debt instruments alongside newer issuances.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2023) → [0.45% Notes due 2016]: Disclosed as part of Officer's Certificate dated May 3, 2013, included in 8-K filing on 5/3/13
Hop 2: [AAPL](2024) → [0.45% Notes due 2016]: Repeated disclosure of the same Officer's Certificate dated May 3, 2013, showing continued inclusion of these notes in capital structure
Hop 3: [AAPL](2022) → [0.45% Notes due 2016]: First documented in 2022 filing as part of the same May 3, 2013 Officer's Certificate

questions.answer: Apple's long-term debt structure with respect to the 4.45% Notes due 2044 remained consistent across 2022, 2023, and 2024, as the notes were first issued in 2014 and were reported in all three annual filings. This multi-year consistency suggests that Apple maintained its long-term financing strategy, retaining the 4.45% Notes as a stable component of its capital structure without early redemption or restructuring during this period.

Hop 2: AAPL(2024) → 4.45% Notes due 2044: The 4.45% Notes due 2044 were again listed in the exhibit table under the same Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014, showing no change in the structure or status of these notes.

Hop 3: AAPL(2022) → 4.45% Notes due 2044: The 4.45% Notes due 2044 were also listed in the 2022 filing under the same Officer's Certificate from 2014, confirming that the notes were a consistent part of Apple's long-term liabilities across all three years.

questions.question: What was the status of Apple's 1.05% Notes due 2017 across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and how does the continued reference to these notes in disclosures reflect Apple's approach to managing maturing debt instruments?
questions.answer: Apple's 1.05% Notes due 2017 were referenced consistently across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024 in its 10-K filings, despite the notes having matured in 2017. In 2022, the notes were listed in Exhibit 4.4 as part of the Officer's Certificate dated May 6, 2014. In 2023, the same notes were again included in Exhibit 4.4 with identical language. In 2024, Apple continued to reference the 1.05% Notes due 2017 in the same exhibit, indicating no change in disclosure strategy. This pattern suggests that Apple may have retained historical references to these notes as part of a standardized disclosure framework, possibly to maintain continuity in its debt documentation or to reflect refinancing activities, though no explicit updates were provided in any of the three years.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2023) → [1.05% Notes due 2017]: Listed in Exhibit 4.4 with no update since 2014, indicating legacy disclosure.
Hop 2: [AAPL](2024) → [1.05% Notes due 2017]: Still referenced in Exhibit 4.4, showing no removal despite maturity in 2017.
Hop 3: [AAPL](2022) → [1.05% Notes due 2017]: Included in Exhibit 4.4, confirming consistent inclusion across all three years.

questions.question: How did Apple's treatment of its 2.40% Notes due 2023 evolve across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this pattern reveal about its short-term debt management and disclosure practices?
questions.answer: Apple's treatment of the 2.40% Notes due 2023 remained consistent across all three fiscal years: the notes were referenced in each year's filing (2022: Exhibit 4.3, 2023: Exhibit 4.3, 2024: Exhibit 4.3), indicating no refinancing or retirement occurred during this period. Despite the notes maturing in 2023, Apple continued to disclose them in both the 2023 and 2024 filings, suggesting a practice of maintaining transparency around legacy debt instruments even after maturity. This consistency in disclosure implies a deliberate approach to capital structure reporting, ensuring stakeholders can track obligations through their full lifecycle, including post-maturity resolution.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [AAPL](2023) → [2.40% Notes due 2023]: The notes were disclosed in Exhibit 4.3 of the 2023 filing, despite their 2023 maturity date, indicating ongoing disclosure obligations.
Hop 2: [AAPL](2024) → [2.40% Notes due 2023]: The notes continued to be disclosed in Exhibit 4.3 of the 2024 filing, showing Apple maintained visibility into its matured obligations.
Hop 3: [AAPL](2022) → [2.40% Notes due 2023]: The notes were included in Exhibit 4.3 of the 2022 filing, establishing a consistent disclosure pattern prior to maturity.
